body: <email>Finn,I'm thrilled that we'll be able to connect on Tuesday afternoon. I've sent you a calendar invite for the call, and I'll include the relevant files and data in advance so you can review them beforehand.Your idea to consult with a paleoclimatologist is brilliant. Understanding the environmental context of the site will undoubtedly provide crucial insights into the lives of the Neolithic people and how they adapted to the challenges posed by the volcanic eruption and changing climate.I've been giving some thought to the potential impact of the eruption on the surrounding landscape, and I believe it could have had a significant effect on the placement and design of the burial site. The presence of volcanic ash and other deposits in the area may have influenced the choice of burial locations and the materials used in the construction of the tombs.I'm also curious to explore any potential ritual or symbolic significance the Neolithic people may have attributed to the volcanic event. It's possible that the eruption and its aftermath played a role in their spiritual beliefs and burial practices.I'll be sure to include these thoughts in our discussion on Tuesday, and I look forward to hearing your perspective on these ideas.Thank you again for your collaboration and enthusiasm, Finn. I have no doubt that our combined expertise will lead to a groundbreaking understanding of this remarkable site and the people who lived through such a transformative event.Best regards,Eleanor

body: <email>Dear Dr. Davis,I hope this email finds you well. My name is Alex Johnson, and I am a student in your Mathematical Problem-Solving in Computer Science course. I am currently working on a project related to cache memory optimization in computer architecture, and I was hoping to seek your advice on how to approach the problem using mathematical modeling techniques.I have been struggling to find an effective way to model the behavior of cache memories and optimize their performance. I believe that your expertise in mathematical modeling and problem-solving could provide valuable insights into this challenge.Would it be possible to schedule a meeting with you to discuss my project in more detail? I would greatly appreciate any guidance you could offer.Thank you for your time and consideration.Best regards,Alex Johnson

body: <email>Hi Emily,Great to hear from you! I'm glad the class went well and that the students found it valuable. I'd definitely be interested in discussing the latest economic data with you further.In terms of the new variants, it's a bit of a mixed bag. On one hand, the increased transmissibility is concerning from a public health perspective. But from an economic standpoint, the fact that they seem to be leading to fewer hospitalizations and deaths is a positive sign.I'm also very interested in moving forward with that research paper idea. I think there's a lot of potential there to explore the cost-effectiveness of different containment strategies. Let me know when you're available to brainstorm next steps.Looking forward to catching up more soon!Best,Alex

body: <email>Hi Alex,Thanks so much for reaching out and for sharing those articles. I'm looking forward to reading them and continuing our conversation.I also wanted to share a recent paper I co-authored on the topic of space governance and international cooperation: "Towards a New Framework for Space Governance: Bridging the Gap Between Law and Practice" (https://www.spacepolicyjournal.com/framework_space_governance.html). I'd be curious to hear your thoughts.It sounds like we have a lot in common, both professionally and personally. I'm always happy to connect people with my colleague in the Alps if you decide to go on that hiking trip!Best,Samir
label: research

body: <email>Dear Ethan,Thank you so much for your enthusiastic response! I am thrilled to have your expertise on board for this project. Your experience with Python libraries and machine learning will be invaluable in helping us uncover the full potential of the data we have collected.I have attached a sample of the satellite data we have gathered, which includes information on the migration routes of humpback, gray, and blue whales over the past five years. Our primary research questions include:1. Identifying key migration routes and timing for each species2. Investigating potential environmental factors influencing migration patterns (e.g., sea surface temperature, prey availability)3. Assessing potential threats to whale populations along their migration routes (e.g., shipping lanes, coastal development)I would be happy to have a call next week to discuss these questions in more detail and begin planning our analysis. I am available Tuesday after 2 PM or Wednesday any time. Please let me know what works best for you.Once again, I am excited to collaborate with you on this project and look forward to combining our skills to make a meaningful impact on whale conservation.Best regards,Olivia SteinmanMarine BiologistMarine Conservation Organization

body: <email>Hi Emily,The week after next works great for me! I think your lecture will be a fantastic supplement to the lessons we've been doing on migration and urbanization. Please do send over the outline whenever you have a chance.I took a look at the lesson plan you sent and I think it looks really strong! You've done a great job incorporating the resources and making the connections between climate change and human impacts clear. One suggestion I had was to maybe include a section on potential solutions or actions individuals can take to mitigate the effects of climate change. I think that could empower your students and give them a sense of agency.I'm looking forward to our continued collaboration and to your guest lecture!Best,Alex

body: Learn Technical AnalysisTwo Full Days, December 4-5, 2001 Early Bird Discount Until October 31, 2001 [IMAGE] Marriott West Loop, Houston, Texas Energy Traders, Marketers and Buyers.   This two full day class serves as both an introduction to those new to technical analysis and a refresher for experienced traders. Technicals are taught in a logical, systematic manner oriented to equip both physical and paper traders to buy low, sell high and manage risk in the real world in a logical, methodical manner.  	  In this class you will:   Ascertain when and how to take profit and cut losses.  Find out how to set up a strategy by identifying probable market direction and turns as well as likely targets using chart patterns.  Learn to use both traditional indicators like moving averages and stochastics, as well the state-of-the-art methods which won Cynthia Kase the coveted Market Technicians Association's "Best of the Best" award.  	 Content   Charting Basics, Types of Charts, Support and Resistance  When to Buy or Sell (Entry Techniques)  When to Exit Based on Signals (Momentum and Divergence)  How to Exit Based on Stops (Managing Trade Risk)  Chart Patterns and Forecasting Basics (Candlesticks, Elliott  Wave, Flags, etc.)  Statistical Hedging  	 Early Bird Special $845.00 Two or More Early Bird $795.00 Regular: $995.00 Two or More: $895.00	 *** Register Now! ***      Click Here for More Information   About the Presenters   Who Should Attend  Detailed Agenda and Schedule  Other Classes Offered By Kase 	   [IMAGE] Kase and Company also offers In House Training Classes. For more information please email us at kase@kaseco.com  or call at (505) 237-1600

body: <email>Dear Dr. Russo,I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to thank you again for the valuable insights you shared during our panel discussion at the Special Education Conference last month. Your expertise in individualized learning strategies for kinesthetic learners was truly inspiring.I've been implementing some of the techniques we discussed, such as incorporating more hands-on activities and group projects into my lessons. I've noticed a significant improvement in my students' engagement and comprehension. I would love to hear about any new strategies you've been exploring recently.Additionally, I've been giving some thought to pursuing a career in educational psychology. I believe it would allow me to have a greater impact on the lives of students with diverse learning needs. I would greatly appreciate any advice or guidance you could offer.I look forward to hearing from you soon.Best regards,Emily

We've been working together for a while now, and your explanations have been so helpful in improving my understanding of the subject.Would you be available for a study session this weekend? I'd really appreciate if we could go over some of the key concepts that will be on the exam, like stoichiometry, the periodic table, and chemical reactions. I'm feeling pretty confident, but I want to make sure I'm fully prepared for the exam.Thanks in advance,Sarah

body: Looks like we are dead in the water based on this message and the one Glenn got. Let's meet to review this morning.-------------------------------------------------------------Gary WaxmanDirector, Enterprise GroupEnron Broadband Services2100 SW River ParkwayPortland, OR 97201Mobile: 503-807-8923Desk:   503-886-0196Fax:     503-886-0441------------------------------------------------------------------ 	curtis.meyer@sap.com	12/15/00 05:54 AM		 		 		  		 Gary,   FYI....-----Original Message-----Sent: Friday, December 15, 2000 6:44 AMCc: Lingner, AnnettHello Curtis,sorry for the late response.An upgrade from E1 to E3 is not an option for the mentioned locations, forthe foreseeable future.The 2. proposal is also not an option for us, because we buy bandwidth ondemand and the demands change very dynamically, therefore such a plan wouldnot fit our requirements.best regards Dietmar----------------------------Original Message-----Sent: Montag, 11. Dezember 2000 17:22Cc: Gooden, Dennis; Bannon, MichaelImportance: HighDietmar,   Attached is a message from Enron Broadband Services on sizing theproposal back to SAP.Hopefully his attached message is clear in terms of finding a way tostructure itfor growth based on your needs.  This would increase the size of ourarrangement if itmakes good sense for you.  Please get back to me with your thoughts.-----Original Message-----Sent: Friday, December 08, 2000 2:19 PMCc: Glenn_Surowiec@enron.net; Matt_Harris@enron.netCurtis - following our phone call this morning I met with Matt Harris andourstructuring person (Glenn Surowiec) to review the deal. After some quickanalysis it looks like we overestimated the opportunity.The circuits Dietmar is requesting is a european E1 which equates to a UST1.The hub (Wallfdorf) -and-spoke (Hungary, Netherlands, UK) model SAP requiresworks out to roughly a $2.09M deal.Clearly this is smaller than both parties would prefer.Thus we would like toknow if there are growth plans for one or more of these connections so thatwecan we propose a larger pipe (i.e. European E3/US DS3).For example if just one of the connections can be an E3 for the entirecontract(ten years) it would bump the value up to $8.5M. Please review this andlet'splan on talking later today. Another model to consider would be toprogressivelybump up the pipe size across all the connections at set intervals (i.e.years1-3 = E1, years 4-6 = E2, years 7-10 = E3).Please let me know what your thoughts are and let's talk ASAP.-------------------------------------------------------------Gary WaxmanDirector, Enterprise GroupEnron Broadband Services2100 SW River ParkwayPortland, OR 97201Mobile: 503-807-8923Desk:   503-886-0196Fax:     503-886-0441-------------------------------------------------------------|--------+----------------------->|        |          curtis.meyer@||        |          sap.com      ||        |                       ||        |          12/08/00     ||        |          09:54 AM     ||        |                       ||--------+----------------------->>----------------------------------------------------------------------------|  ||  |       |  |            dennis.gooden@sap.com, michael.bannon@sap.com|  |       |>----------------------------------------------------------------------------|

body: <email>Dear Samantha,Thank you for reaching out, and it's great to hear from you again. I remember our brief interaction at the conference last year and appreciate your interest in our work.I would be happy to provide an interview for your article on the new melanoma treatment. As one of the lead researchers on the clinical trial, I can share insights into the treatment's mechanism of action, its potential benefits, and the next steps for further research and development.I'm available for a phone interview next week, either on Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning. Please let me know which time works best for you, and feel free to send me any specific questions you have in advance.I also noticed that you mentioned a passion for hiking and camping in your email signature. My wife and I are planning a hiking trip in the Rocky Mountains next month. Do you have any favorite spots or trails you'd recommend?I look forward to our interview and to sharing more about our exciting research.Best regards,Dr. Michael ChenSkin Oncology Research Institute

body: <email>Dear Robert,Thank you for your feedback on my draft and for sharing your outline for our discussion. I have reviewed your comments and found them to be extremely helpful. I think your suggestions will strengthen the paper and help us to better integrate our research.I have also looked over your outline and agree that the points you have listed are crucial for our collaboration. I have added a few additional topics that I think we should cover during our meeting:1. The role of Galileo's trial in shaping the public perception of the heliocentric theory2. The impact of the Protestant Reformation on the reception of the heliocentric theory in different European regions3. Potential implications of our research for contemporary debates about science and religionI look forward to discussing these topics and more during our video conference on Wednesday.Best regards,Emily Johnson

body: If you cannot read this email, please click here .=20Earnings.com - NewsEarnings.com =09[IMAGE] =09=09     AXP   29.17 -0.15    American Express Company Reports Third Quarter= Net Income of $298 Million=1D(millions, except per share amounts) Quarter =Percentage Nine Percentage Ended Inc/ Months Inc/ September 30 (Dec) Ended =(Dec) September 30 2001 2000 2001 2000 Net Income* $298 $737 (60%) $1,014 $=2,133 (52%) Net Revenues** $5,478 $5,554 (1%) $15,770 $16,371 (4%) Per Shar=e Net Income Basic $0  23 $0.56 (59%) $0.77 $1.61 (52%) Diluted $0.22 $0.54= (59%) $0.76 $1.57 (52%) Average Common Shares Outstanding Basic 1,324 1,32=6 -- 1,323 1,328 -- Diluted 1,335 1,361 (2%) 1,338 1,361 (2%) Return on Ave=rage Equity 14.2% 25.5% -- 14.2% 25.5% --   NEW YORK, Oct 22, 2001 /PRNewsw=ire via COMTEX/ -- American Express Company (NYSE: AXP) today reported thir=d quarter net income of $298 million, down 60 percent from $737 million in =the same period a year ago. Diluted earnings per share were $.22, down 59 p=ercent from a year ago. Net revenues on a managed basis totaled $5.5 billio=n, down one percent from $5.6 billion a year ago. The company's return on e=quity was 14.2 percent.   Results for the third quarter were negatively aff=ected by two significant items: a previously announced restructuring charge= of $352 million pre-tax ($232 million after-tax) and the impacts from the =September 11th terrorist attacks.   The September 11th events resulted in c=ertain one-time costs and business interruption losses, including: provisio=ns related to credit exposures to travel industry service establishments, i=nsurance claims, and waived finance charges and late fees. The combination =of these items totaled approximately $98 million pre-tax ($65 million after=-tax).   The company also incurred costs of approximately $42 million since= September 11th, which are expected to be covered by insurance. Consequentl=y, these costs did not impact the quarterly results. These include the cost= of duplicate facilities and equipment associated with the relocation of th=e company's offices in lower Manhattan and certain other business recovery =expenses. Costs associated with the damage to the company's offices, extra =operating expenses and business interruption losses are still being evaluat=ed. The company expects that a substantial portion ofgh its Ists and losses= will be covered by insurance.   The third quarter restructuring charge inc=ludes severance costs for the elimination of approximately 6,100 jobs and a=sset impairment and other costs, all relating to the consolidation and reor=ganization of certain business units, the scale back of corporate lending i=n certain regions, the migration of certain processes to lower cost locatio=ns, the outsourcing of certain activities, and the transition of certain pr=ocessing and service functions to the Internet. These initiatives are expec=ted to produce expense savings of approximately $325 million in 2002. A por=tion of these savings is expected to flow through to earnings in the form o=f improved operating expense margins and the rest is expected to be reinves=ted back into high-growth areas of the business.   In addition to the activ=ities related to the restructuring charge, the company made strong progress= on its global reengineering efforts initiated in the first half of the yea=r and, as of September 30, had realized savings in excess of $700 million. =  Net income for the third quarter, adjusted for the restructuring and one-=time costs related to September 11th, was approximately $595 million, down =19 percent. On a similar basis, earnings per share were $.45, down 17 perce=nt. The company's adjusted return on equity was 16.7 percent.   "While we w=ere on target to meet prior consensus for third quarter earnings, the terro=rist attacks obviously had a significant impact on the overall economy and =we saw clear evidence of that as consumer spending, business travel and inv=estment activity slowed after September 11th," said Kenneth I. Chenault, ch=airman and chief executive officer, American Express Company. "In light of =the weak economy and financial markets, we are moving aggressively to lower= our operating expenses. The progress we are making on our reengineering in=itiatives has freed up substantial resources for investment in our business=es with the strongest growth potential. This, along with the anticipated be=nefit of lower interest rates and the strategies in place to grow our franc=hise, positions us well to benefit when we see even a modest improvement in= the economy."   Travel Related Services (TRS) reported quarterly net incom=e of $248 million, down 51 percent from $507 million in the third quarter a= year ago. Included in third quarter results are $195 million pre-tax ($127= million after-tax) of the restructuring charge noted earlier. Also include=d in the results are $87 million pre-tax ($57 million after-tax) of one-tim=e costs and waived fees directly related to the September 11th terrorist at=tacks. Excluding these costs and the restructuring charge, TRS' net income =would have been $432 million, down 15 percent from the third quarter last y=ear.   TRS' net revenues rose two percent, as growth in loans and fee reven=ues were partly offset by a three percent decline in billed business and a =28 percent fall in travel sales. These declines reflect a substantial decre=ase in corporate travel and entertainment spending and consumer travel sinc=e September 11th. Prior to September, billed business growth for the quarte=r was about two percent as higher consumer and small business spending offs=et a decline in corporate travel and entertainment spending. Net finance ch=arge revenues were higher, due to balance growth and wider net interest yie=lds. This increase reflects a smaller percentage of loan balances on introd=uctory rates and the benefit of declining interest rates during the quarter=.   The provision for losses on the lending portfolios grew as a result of =higher volumes and an increase in U.S. lending write-off rates and delinque=ncies. Marketing and promotion expenses were lower as TRS scaled back certa=in marketing efforts in light of the weaker business environment. Operating= expenses rose, reflecting increased Cardmember loyalty programs and busine=ss volumes. These expenses were partly offset by the benefits of reengineer=ing and cost-control efforts.   The above discussion presents TRS results "=on a managed basis" as if there had been no securitization transactions, wh=ich conforms to industry practice. The attached financials present TRS resu=lts on both a managed and reported basis. Net income is the same in both fo=rmats.   On a reported basis, TRS' results included securitization gains of= $29 million pre-tax ($19 million after-tax) and $26 million pre-tax ($17 m=illion after-tax) in the third quarters of 2001 and 2000, respectively. The=se gains were offset by expenses related to card acquisition activities and= therefore had no material impact on net income or total expenses.   Americ=an Express Financial Advisors (AEFA) reported quarterly net income of $145 =million, down 46 percent from $269 million in the third quarter a year ago.= Net revenues decreased 14 percent. Included in third quarter results are $=62 million pre-tax ($41 million after-tax) of the restructuring charge note=d earlier and $11 million pre-tax ($8 million after-tax) of insurance claim=s directly related to September 11th. Excluding these items, AEFA's net inc=ome would have been $194 million, down 28 percent from last year.   AEFA re=sults reflect continued weakness in equity markets and narrower spreads on =the investment portfolio. The weakened equity markets led to significantly =lower asset levels and lower sales of investment products. As a result, man=agement and distribution fees fell 15 percent.   Operating expenses, exclud=ing the above-mentioned charges, decreased four percent from a year ago due= primarily to lower sales commissions and continued reengineering and cost-=control initiatives.   As of September 30th, approximately 4 percent of the= company's $33 billion investment portfolio consisted of high-yield securit=ies, down from 12 percent a year ago and 8 percent last quarter. The reduct=ion reflects the activities to date to lower the risk profile of the portfo=lio and concentrate on stronger credits.   American Express Bank (AEB) repo=rted a quarterly net loss of $43 million, compared with $7 million of net i=ncome a year ago. Included in third quarter results are $84 million pre-tax= ($57 million after-tax) of the restructuring charge noted earlier. Excludi=ng these charges, AEB's net income would have been $15 million, approximate=ly double the earnings recorded in the same period last year.   While AEB s=ustained damage to its premises due to the September 11th terrorist attacks=, the costs are expected to be covered by insurance. Consequently, these co=sts did not impact AEB's quarterly results.   AEB's business results reflec=t strong performance in Personal Financial Services and Private Banking. Re=sults also benefited from lower funding costs and lower operating expenses =as a result of AEB's reengineering efforts. body: <email>Aisha,I completely agree with your suggestion for structuring the paper. Having each of us take the lead on sections that align with our expertise and perspectives, while ensuring an overall balanced approach, will make for a stronger and more compelling piece.As for specific aspects to focus on, I think it's crucial that we examine the historical context of the conflict, particularly the events leading up to the current flare-up in violence. We should also analyze the geopolitical implications, both in terms of India-Pakistan relations and the broader regional dynamics (e.g., China's role, the impact on Afghanistan, etc.).Additionally, I believe we should address the human rights issues at play, particularly the plight of the Kashmiri people caught in the middle of this long-standing dispute. This is an area where I think your insights and expertise would be particularly valuable.Let's touch base next week to finalize our outline and divide up the research and writing tasks. I'm happy to take the lead on the historical and geopolitical sections, while you focus on the human rights aspects and the Kashmiri perspective.Looking forward to our continued collaboration!Best regards,Rajesh

It's a fascinating piece of history that could really enhance our presentation.I think we should definitely incorporate this new information. It might require some last-minute adjustments, but I believe it will be worth it. We'll need to carefully consider how this letter fits into our overall narrative and how it supports our thesis.I suggest we set up a video call to discuss our strategy for integrating this new document. Are you available tomorrow afternoon, say around 2 PM EST? If not, let me know what works best for you.I'm looking forward to diving deeper into this new material and refining our presentation.Best,Daniel

body: <email>Hi Emily,That's fantastic news! I'm thrilled that we have the opportunity to present our work at such a prestigious conference. I completely agree that our collaborative approach and the innovative teaching materials we've created would be of great interest to the conference attendees.I'm available next Tuesday afternoon, around 2 PM, for a planning session. Does that work for you? If not, let me know your preferred day and time, and I'll do my best to accommodate.I've been giving some thought to the workshop content, and I think we should focus on demonstrating how our teaching materials engage students and foster a deeper understanding of chemistry concepts. We could also discuss the process we went through to develop these materials and how we've incorporated feedback from our students to refine them.Looking forward to our meeting and the exciting work ahead!Best,Michael

body: <email>Hi Michael,I hope you're doing well. I have some exciting news to share! We've been invited to present a joint workshop at the upcoming National Science Education Conference. The conference theme is "Innovative Teaching Methods in STEM Education: Empowering the Next Generation of Scientists," and I think it's a perfect opportunity for us to showcase our collaborative work and the unique teaching materials we've developed together.I would love to meet and discuss our ideas for the workshop. Are you available next week for a planning session? Let me know what day and time work best for you.Best regards,Emily
label: research

body: <email>Hey Michael,I hope you're doing well! I'm reaching out because I'm working on a proposal for a new solar telescope that could revolutionize our understanding of the sun's atmosphere. I remember you mentioned at the conference a few years ago that you were interested in how stellar evolution impacts galaxy formation, and I think this technology could be a game-changer for your research as well.The proposed telescope would use advanced adaptive optics to achieve unprecedented resolution and sensitivity in the UV and X-ray wavelengths, allowing us to study the sun's magnetic field and coronal mass ejections in much greater detail than ever before. I'm thinking this could also be applied to studying the formation and evolution of massive stars in distant galaxies, which could shed light on the role of dark matter in galaxy formation.I'd love to get your thoughts on this and see if you'd be interested in collaborating on the proposal. Let me know if you have any questions or ideas!Best,Sarah
label: research

Conversion and Arbitrage Problems: We will brainstorm ways toincorporate more problems without going over our 4-6 hour target. We willmeet with you next Tuesday at 10:00 to review the problems as we'vedesigned them so far and arrive at a solution. (I will send an e-mailMonday with the room number.)Have a good weekend.MeryThis message is for the designated recipient only and may containprivileged, proprietary, or otherwise private information.  If you havereceived it in error, please notify the sender immediately and delete theoriginal.  Any other use of the email by you is prohibited.

body: <email>Emily,I'm glad my advice was helpful! I think you'd be a great fit for a museum role, given your passion for archaeological research and your excellent communication skills. I'll reach out to a few colleagues and put you in touch with them.In the meantime, I'd recommend updating your CV to highlight your relevant experience and skills. When I was applying for museum jobs, I focused on my research expertise, my ability to interpret and present complex information to diverse audiences, and my experience with project management and collaboration.Feel free to send me your updated CV, and I can provide feedback and suggestions based on what I've learned through my own job search.Best of luck with your career transition! I'm here to support you every step of the way.Liam

body: <email>Hi Liam,Tuesday at 2 PM works perfectly for me. Let's meet in the faculty lounge â€“ it's a nice, relaxed setting for brainstorming.I've been thinking about how we can incorporate cost-benefit analysis and production theory into the course while also addressing social and emotional development. I believe that by providing students with a strong foundation in economic principles, we can then explore how these concepts play out in real-world scenarios, particularly in terms of social dynamics and equity.I'd love to hear your initial thoughts on this approach and any ideas you have for specific topics or activities we could include in the course.See you on Tuesday!Best,Amelia

body: <email>Jenna,I'm so glad you brought this up! I've been brainstorming ideas as well and absolutely love the concept of focusing on modern and contemporary art. The students will be thrilled to learn about these iconic art movements and create their own masterpieces.I think we should also consider incorporating some interactive art projects, like a collaborative mural or a sculpture garden. This will allow the kids to work together and engage with art in a more hands-on way.Let's set up a video call next week to discuss our plans in more detail. I can't wait to see what we come up with for the camp!Best,Alex

body: <email>Hi Olivia,Thank you for reaching out about this fantastic project! I think it's a wonderful idea and a great opportunity for my students to learn about the environment and the role of trees in our ecosystem.I would love to integrate this project into our curriculum. We could teach the students about the science behind trees, their importance, and how they can contribute to the health of our planet. It would be great if you could come to our classroom to give a presentation about your work and the importance of environmental conservation.Additionally, I was thinking we could organize a field trip to a local nature reserve or forest to give the students a real-life experience of the topics we'll be learning about. What do you think?I'm excited to collaborate on this project and look forward to your thoughts.Best,Michael

body: <email>Dear Mr. Green,I hope this email finds you well. I'm Emily Johnson, a mathematics teacher at Ridgemont Middle School, and I believe we are neighbors. I'm reaching out to you because my students are working on a project that involves using coding to optimize garden layouts and planting schedules. Given your expertise in gardening, particularly in USDA Hardiness Zone 8, I was wondering if you might be willing to share some insights with us.The students are participating in a school-wide science fair, and their project aims to create a sustainable garden using computational thinking. Your advice on gardening techniques specific to our climate zone would be invaluable in helping them create more accurate and effective garden plans.If you have any time in the coming weeks, I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to discuss this project with you further. Please let me know if you would be interested in mentoring my students or providing any guidance on this project.Thank you for considering my request. I look forward to hearing from you soon.Best regards,Emily Johnson

body: The project coordinators believe they can reach a solution with Accenture in which Enron pays no additional fees but the project is completed in a slightly scaled back form.  This allows Accenture to have a completed project and no more cash goes out the door.The effort from the SME's should be complete by Christmas.  Please push forward with the review of the knowledge layer.Phillip -----Original Message-----Sent:	Tuesday, November 20, 2001 2:51 PMCc:	O'rourke, Tim; Coleman, Brad; McDaniel, KirkPhillip,It will go along this lines: (Conservative)*****************************************************We pay "0" going forwardWe have already played 300K in 3Q2001Outstanding bill for $27,740 will hit Enron Q1, 2002Enron and surviving entity will have the right to use it internallyWe value Enrons SME time @ around 300KAccenture will have the right to use it internally and modify the product at its will for internal & external use.This arrangement will void 900K Enrons Revenue from AccentureEnron would receive 0% royalty on all external sales.  I was thinking to stay away from royalty as we do not know what will be new company position on this matter. Also,  I do not think Accenture will want to enter into partnership structure with a ghost company unless we get Dinergy involved.***********************************************************************If we do not reach the agreement: 1. Terminate and pay around 500-600k (estimate)  The payment could be deferred in to 2Q 2002 or				 2. Continue "as is" with payment differed for 90 days or merger.We are sending Accenture official notice as of tomorrow we have 10 business days to workout solution or terminate.	Any comments or suggestions?Regards,Yevgeny  -----Original Message-----Sent:	Tuesday, November 20, 2001 12:32 PMYevgeny,Please send me an email describing the zero option so I can pass it along to the other SME's.Phillip -----Original Message-----Sent:	Monday, November 19, 2001 10:26 AMCc:	McDaniel, Kirk; Coleman, Brad; O'rourke, TimImportance:	HighPhillip,I am following up to our BRM conversation from Friday.  Obviously it is a valid questions to ask and as you requested I am attaching two documents: one summarizing the options and  2nd cash flow impact.  In the cash flow impact Case 2 & 3 already account for additional cut of 100k from existing cost.  (it comes from Expenses such as projected traveling 30K+Cut in Media 20K + Cut in sim exercises 50K)  The cut in sim exercises need to be confirmed with you. A total of two sims could be cut one.  Accenture will address this question tomorrow during the meeting.  Also,  I will ask them to cut the meeting by 10 min, thus we can go over the documents and can answer your questions.  I am not sure what is Tim's schedule for tomorrow, but at least Kirk and myself will be around. Obviously cutting sims is not the best options but we are considering all alternatives at this time.  We will continue to review how to cut labor and expenses.One question that it would be good if you think about it before we meet is as follow.  Is BRM "core" to the Enron for next few months or new organization?  Please consider the costs of finishing this project.Sincerely,Yevgeny Frolov713-345-8250 w << File: BRM Cash Flow Cases.xls >>  << File: BRM Contingency Numbers Rev3.xls >>

body: thanks  FYI. I spoke with Steve. Seems like they have not been successful with plan A, i.e. to get their investors to give them authority to trade OTC as well as futures. They have moved on to plan B which is to take one of their domestic funds (approx. $500mm under mgt) off the floor (futures only) and into OTC trading. Still has the rating problem with Enron, but I am trying to get him to arrange a conference call with their CFO so I can discuss ways around it. He will try to do so this week. Mind you, I left it at this point the last time I spoke with him a couple of months ago and it seemed to stall. I'll keep chasing it. One is setting up their internal systems.  Second, they have credit problems with a BBB+.Please call and introduce yourself.Thanks,john   John, did you answer him or should I respond? body: <email>Hi Robert,I hope you're doing well. As you know, our department chair has asked us to collaborate on a grant proposal for a research project on the application of econometric models in economic forecasting. I think this is a great opportunity for us to combine our expertise and work on a project that could have a significant impact on our field.I was thinking about potential research questions, and I believe we should focus on the following: "How can econometric models be used to improve short-term and long-term economic forecasting accuracy?" What are your thoughts on this? Do you have any suggestions for refining the question or other aspects of the proposal?Please let me know your availability for a meeting to discuss this further. I'm excited to work with you on this project!Best regards,Emily

I'm thrilled that we'll have the opportunity to work together on this important project.I've attached the official acceptance letter and the grant agreement for your review. Please take a look and let me know if you have any questions or concerns.I think it would be best for us to meet in person to finalize the study design and plan for data collection. Would you be available to meet in Geneva next month? I can arrange for a meeting room at the WHO headquarters. Let me know your preferred dates, and I'll make the necessary arrangements.Looking forward to hearing from you and getting started on this exciting project!Best regards,Emily

body: <email>Hi Alex,It was great meeting you at the science education conference last week! I really enjoyed your presentation on engaging ways to explain weather phenomena. As I mentioned, I'm a high school chemistry teacher focused on molecular orbital theory and atomic structure. I think our areas of expertise could complement each other well for a collaborative project.I had an idea: what if we create a series of blog posts and videos that explore the connections between chemistry and weather? For example, we could look at how atomic structure relates to the formation of clouds or how molecular orbital theory can help explain the formation of ozone. We could share these materials on our social media channels and websites to reach a wider audience.What do you think? If you're interested, we can discuss the logistics of the project, such as timelines, content creation, and promotion strategies.I look forward to hearing your thoughts!Best regards,Emily Chen
label: research

body: <email>Hi Michael,I hope you're doing well! It's been a while since we last chatted, but I've been thinking about our conversations about teaching introductory econometrics and thought of an idea for a potential research project.I was wondering if you'd be interested in collaborating on a study examining the effectiveness of different instructional methods in intro econ courses. I've been experimenting with some new approaches in my classes and have been curious to see if they make a significant difference in student learning outcomes. I know you've also been doing some innovative things in your classes at UNC.If you're open to it, I'd love to discuss the possibility of designing a study together. We could potentially apply for grant funding to support the work.Let me know if this piques your interest! I'd be happy to set up a call to brainstorm further.Best,Emily

It would be an honor to experience Jamaican hospitality firsthand, and I'm sure it will make our trip even more memorable.I can't wait to see your list of must-visit places! I'll start looking into any additional activities or experiences we might want to include in our itinerary.Thanks again for everything, Jamal. I'm so grateful to have you as my guide and friend on this adventure. Let's make some unforgettable memories together!Best regards,Petra

body: <email>Hey Michael,I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out because I've finally completed the draft for the first section of our dictionary project. I've attached the file to this email, and I would really appreciate it if you could take a look and provide some feedback.As I was working on this, I started thinking about how our research could potentially contribute to the field of lexicography. What do you think about the idea of co-authoring a paper on our findings once the dictionary is complete? I think it could be a great opportunity to share our work with the wider linguistic community.Let me know your thoughts on both the draft and the paper idea. I'm excited to hear your feedback and continue working on this project together.Best regards,Sarah

body: <email>Hey Michael,I hope you're doing well! I wanted to share something exciting with you that I learned at the chemistry education conference last week. I attended a session on a new teaching method called "Modeling Instruction" that I think could be really beneficial for our students.The basic idea behind Modeling Instruction is to engage students in building and testing mental models of chemical concepts through a series of guided inquiries and activities. The goal is to help students develop a deeper understanding of the underlying principles and mechanisms of chemistry.I've attached a few resources that provide an overview of the method and some example activities. I'd love to hear your thoughts on it and discuss whether we might be able to incorporate some of these ideas into our curriculum.Let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to chat more about this!Best,Emily

body: Gentlemen,Today I finally received some information on the status of the work done to date.  I spoke to Hugo Alexandro at Cuatro Consultants.  The property is still in two parcels.  Hugo has completed a platt to combine into one  lot and is ready to submit it to the city of San Marcos.  He has also completed a topographical survey and a tree survey.  In addition, he has begun to coordinate with the city on the replatting and a couple of easements on the smaller parcel, as well as, beginning the work on the grading.  Hugo is going to fax me a written letter of the scope of work he has been engaged to complete.  The total cost of his services are estimated at $38,000 of which $14,000 are due now for work completed.  We are trying to resolve the issues of outstanding work and bills incurred by the original developer so we can obtain the title to the land.  If we can continue to use Cuatro then it would be one less point of contention.  Hugo's number is 512-295-8052.  I thought you might want to contact him directly and ask him some questions.  I spoke to him about the possibility of your call and he was fine with that.  Now we are going to try and determine if any of the work performed by Kipp Flores can be used.Keith and I appreciate you meeting with us on Sunday.  We left very optimistic about the prospect of working with you on this project.Call me with feedback after you speak to Hugo or with any other ideas about moving this project forward.Phillip

body: Hello Professor Nair, Iâ€™m eager to join your research lab. Could you let me know what the requirements are and how I can apply?
label: student

body: <email>Dear Dr. Silva,Thank you for reaching out and for your interest in a potential collaboration. I, too, found our conversation at the conference to be thought-provoking and believe that our respective fields of research could complement each other well.Your work on the political factors influencing environmental policy in Brazil is particularly relevant to my research on the Galapagos Islands, where government policy plays a crucial role in managing invasive species and protecting the unique ecosystems. I would be very interested in exploring how the transition from authoritarianism to democracy in Brazil has impacted environmental policy and conservation efforts, and how this might compare to other island contexts.I will send you some of my recent publications on invasive species management in the Galapagos, and I would be keen to read your work on Brazilian environmental policy. Perhaps we could arrange a video call in the coming weeks to discuss our research in more detail and brainstorm potential collaborative projects?Please let me know your availability, and I will be happy to coordinate a time that works for both of us.Best regards,James
label: research

body: <email>Dear Rafiq,I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out to share some exciting news about our MHM education project. We've finally developed a set of age-appropriate educational materials that we'll be piloting in local schools next month. I've attached a copy of the materials for your review and feedback.I'm curious to know how your handwashing campaign is going. Have you encountered any challenges in promoting behavior change among the community members?Looking forward to hearing from you soon.Best regards,Alice
label: research

body: John,Thanks for the email and the offer to route my resume in the mostexpeditious way.  I saw only one job that was posted on Enron's website thatlooked like a good fit.  It was an asset evaluation and integration job forEnron North America: job # 0000105886.My primary strengths are:Natural gas asset acquisition and managementSupporting a trading organization by providing excellent futures andderivatives executionTrading proprietary books (fixed price or otherwise)where there is acompetitive reason to be     in the market, i.e. transportation spreads,storage, physical presenceGood customer relations/account developmentAbility to focus on and analyze a wide range of problems/opportunitiesStong negotiatorI know that Enron is a big, happening place and it is invaluble to havesomeone like you to help me sort out the opportunities.  Where I am comingfrom is that I have to more valuble to Enron than I am to Oxy because Oxy isdoing frustratingly little to leverage itself and Enron is setting everytrend imaginable in leveraging itself.I appreciate any help you can provide.Thanks.Alan-----Original Message-----Sent: Wednesday, November 08, 2000 5:15 PMAlan:I received your email.  I'll make sure it goes through the proper channels.It may help if you give specific positions that interest you most as Enronis such a big place, it will help focus the resume to the right people.John
label: corporate

body: Frank:Just following up on two topics.One: Larry May's book continues to run at a VAR of 2,500,00 despite the fact his P&L is never close to that.  Can you check that his exotics book positions are being picked up in his VAR calcs.Second:  Have you looked into applying a band-aid to the understating longer term Vol problem until we change formulas?John
label: corporate

body: <email>Hi Emily,I hope you're doing well. I wanted to share some exciting news with you regarding our Gulf Stream project. Over the past few weeks, I've been working on a new software tool that I believe could significantly improve the efficiency of our model.The tool utilizes a novel algorithm to optimize the computational process, potentially reducing the time required for simulations by up to 50%. I've conducted some initial tests, and the results look promising.Before presenting this tool to the rest of the team, I wanted to get your feedback. Would you be available for a quick call this week to discuss the tool and its potential implications for our research? I'd be happy to provide a demo and answer any questions you may have.Let me know your availability, and I'll set up a meeting.Best regards,Alex
label: research

body: <email>Hey Alex,I hope you're doing well! I was cleaning out my office this weekend and came across some geometry lesson plans I thought you might find useful. They're from a unit I taught last year on circles and tangents. I remember you mentioned struggling to find engaging activities for that topic.Let me know if you want me to send them over. I can also grab lunch sometime if you're free. It's been too long since we've caught up properly!Best,Emily
label: research

body: I am changing the way the curve is generated starting in Jan 2004 to better replicate seasonal fundamentals.  There are convincing arguments as to why the summer/winter spreads should tighten over time.  However, in the previous methodology they blew out.  For instance summer/winter in Cal 3 was .232 while Cal 10 was .256.  I have added a seasonality dampening function that both contracts the summer/winter spread and applies a premium to the electric load demand months of July and August over time.The formula for the curve remains the same except for a premium lookup for the month as well as for the year.  These premiums are as follows:Jan  -.008Feb -.004Mar -.001Apr .002May .003Jun .004Jul .004Aug .004Sep .003Oct .002Nov -.003Dec -.006These premiums start in Jan 2004On Wednesday Jan 2003 settled 2.959,  the 3/4 spread was marked at .0375, the 4/5 spread was marked at .0475.  In the old methodologyJan 2003  = 2.959Jan 2004  = 2.959 + .0375 = 2.9965Jan 2005  =          2.9965 + .0475 = 3.044In the new methodologyJan 2003  = 2.959Jan 2004  = 2.959 + .0375 - .008 =2.9885Jan 2005  = 2.9885 + .0475 -.008 = 3.028The only change in the formula is from:Month x = Month (x- 1 year) + lookup on year on year tabletoMonth x = Month (x- 1 year) + lookup on year on year table + lookup on month premium tableThe seasonality premiums will change over time and I will let you know when I change them
label: student

body: <email>Emily,Thank you for your email and suggestions. I agree with all of your points and think they will greatly strengthen our proposal.I particularly like your idea of emphasizing the potential impact of our research in the introduction. Highlighting the recent droughts and the urgency of the issue will certainly grab the reviewers' attention.I also think providing more details on the polymers and their synthesis is crucial. We want to make sure the reviewers understand the technical aspects of our project and how it differs from previous approaches.As for the scalability discussion, I believe it's essential to show that our research has the potential to make a significant impact beyond the local level. I can draft a brief section on this and send it to you for your input.Please go ahead and make the changes you suggested. I'll review the updated draft on Friday and provide any feedback I may have. We should definitely have enough time to make any final adjustments before the deadline.I echo your sentiment â€“ it's been a pleasure collaborating with you on this project. Your expertise in biochemistry has been invaluable, and I believe our interdisciplinary approach will make our proposal stand out.Best regards,David
label: research

The payoff on the note would be $36,248 ($36090(principal) + $158 (accrued interest)).This is assuming we wrap this up on Tuesday.  Please email to confirm that their changes are ok so I can set up a meeting on Tuesday to reach closure.Phillip

body: <email>Hi Emily,I just had a chance to read through your TED Talk script and I think it's fantastic! You've done a great job weaving in relatable examples and storytelling to make the science accessible. I especially loved the analogy about the radiation therapy being like a precisely targeted "tiny army" attacking the cancer cells. That's such a powerful way to help people understand the concept.I think this talk is going to be a huge hit and I'm so excited for you! Your work is making such an impact and it's wonderful that you're sharing it with the world in such an engaging way.I'll see you soon at the science fair! Let me know if you need anything else.Best,Michael
label: research

body: I hope you are well. Iâ€™m writing to ask for the lecture slides and readings from the Research Methods class. Unfortunately, I missed the last few lectures because I was ill. I would appreciate it if you could share the materials so I can catch up. Thank you for your assistance! Sincerely,
label: student

body: <email>Liam,Thank you for sending the calendar invite. I've accepted it and added the Zoom link to my schedule.I completely agree with the themes you've suggested for the stories. Focusing on healthy eating habits, physical activity, emotional well-being, and hygiene and disease prevention is crucial, especially in the current context. We could also consider incorporating messages about the importance of sleep and limiting screen time, as these are often overlooked aspects of child health.Your idea to create a framework or guidelines for adapting the stories to different cultural contexts is brilliant. We could consult with experts in cultural competence and early childhood education to ensure our approach is inclusive and effective.I've been thinking about potential funding sources for our project. I have some contacts at the World Health Organization and UNICEF who might be interested in supporting our initiative. I'd be happy to reach out to them and explore the possibilities.Looking forward to our call next week to discuss these ideas further!Best,Sophia
label: research

body: <email>Dear Dr. Johnson,Our meeting on Tuesday was incredibly productive, and I'm thrilled with the direction we've decided to take the project. The students will be researching and creating digital art pieces based on the following events:1. The signing of the Treaty of Paris (1783)2. The Whiskey Rebellion (1794)3. The Louisiana Purchase (1803)4. The Battle of New Orleans (1815)I've created a shared folder with resources for each event, which I've shared with you. Please feel free to add any additional resources you think would be helpful for the students.I'll introduce the project to the students next week and begin the research phase. We'll keep you updated on their progress, and we can schedule another meeting to discuss their initial ideas for the digital art pieces.Thank you again for your collaboration and expertise. I know this project will be a success thanks to your involvement.Best regards,Sarah Thompson

body: <email>Hi Jenna,It's great to hear from you! Congratulations on your new position - that's exciting news. I'm happy to share some insights and strategies that have worked well for me in creating inclusive school environments.One of the most important things, I've found, is to start by building relationships with key stakeholders - administrators, teachers, parents, and students. It's crucial to have open and honest conversations about the needs of students with disabilities and to collaborate on developing policies and practices that support their success.Another key strategy is to provide ongoing professional development and training for educators, focusing on best practices for teaching and supporting students with disabilities. It's also important to ensure that accommodations and modifications are consistently implemented and that students have access to the tools and resources they need to thrive academically and socially.I'd be happy to share more detailed recommendations and resources, and I'm also curious to learn more about your new role and the specific challenges you anticipate. It sounds like an exciting opportunity to make a real difference for your students!Best,Alex

body: Good plan.I agree re SJ.  She is on the ball.mh	Patrick Tucker	12/14/00 04:28 PM				 		  Dale Clark/Enron Communications@Enron Communications		 I agree.  Sarah-Joy and I had a detailed follow-on conversation today about this topic, and we're in agreement as to how things can move forward.  I'd definitely like to have Bill rejoin our conversation with our new overall commercial contact at HP, whose name Greg Pyle and Bill Lovejoy will supply in the very near future.  I understand that Peter Goebel was quite clear with HP in today's meetings regarding the imminent nature of his wireless decision, the breadth of vendors with whom he could conceivably do business, and the fact that the wireless deal and the Enron sell side are inextricably linked.  Sarah-Joy mentioned that Gerry has not been present in the more recent conversations, which we're taking to indicate that Bill and Greg understand that his focus was different than ours.  Sarah-Joy has brought immense focus and organization to this process.  I have certainly found her involvement invaluable.  Patrick	Matt Harris	12/14/00 10:51 AM				 		  Dale Clark/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Jennifer Medcalf/NA/Enron@Enron, Patrick Tucker/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Peter Goebel/NA/Enron@Enron		 This is an excellent update.  Thanks for putting this together.Dale/Patrick - lets regroup on how we want to move this onward.  Seems like SJ's suggestion of our spending more time with Bill Dwyer is a good one.ThanksMatt	Sarah-Joy Hunter@ENRON	12/12/00 02:42 PM		 		 		  Patrick Tucker/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Peter Goebel/NA/Enron@Enron, Dale Clark/Enron Communications@Enron Communications, Jennifer Medcalf/NA/Enron@Enron		 Matt:As GSS Business Development transitions the HP relationship for broadband to your team, there are several issues I wanted to clarify in terms of how the relationship has been developed and who the contacts have been to date.  Additionally, I outlined the discussion points/action items from this morning's meeting you held with Jennifer Medcalf and myself.  Per your request, the HP presentation complete with a listing of HP's business partners was e-mailed to you this morning.HP contacts to date: Bill Lovejoy, Western Gulf Area Sales ManagerHouston, TX#(713)-439-5587(Gerry Cashiola's boss)Gerry Cashiola, sales representative Houston, TX#(713)-439-5555(To date, HP person coordinating the relationship--seeking a short term play)Greg Pyle, Solution Control ManagerSoutheast RegionAustin, TX (#(512)-257-5735(Pyle has been playing the business developer role but continues to defer leadership of the process to Gerry Cashiola)Daniel Morgridge, Manager of Internet - E-Services long term alliancesAustin, TX#(512)-257-5736(Interested in E-services/wireless longer term alliances)Bill Dwyer, Chief Architect, e-Services SolutionsCupertino, CA#(408)-447-5240(To date, clearly the most knowledgeable person on HP's business propositions; strong technical, financial background to craft value propositions.  Gerry Cashiola and Greg Pyle deferred to his judgement in the 11/16th meeting)Matt, On November 10th, GSS Business Development took HP through a tour of Enron's trading floor, the gas control center, and the peaking power plant unit center on the trading floor.  This tour was one meeting, amongst several, held in October and November to provide HP a full overview of Enron's products and services and introduce them to appropriate contacts at Enron (EBS, GSS buy side -- Peter Goebel).On November 16th GSS Business Development,  Patrick Tucker, and Dale Clark outlined 3 possible EBS/HP focus areas  --  connectivity, storage, and wireless.  Three EBS action items were defined in that meeting:1) HP was to provide an HP contact on connectivity (to date, Gerry Cashiola has stalled on providing this).  Sarah-Joy will continue to pursue this information and get a sense from Gerry Cashiola of what he means by short term opportunity.  What is HP's time horizon for short term?2) EBS and GSS/BD was to facilitate a conference call on Storage with Ravi to explore size and potential scope of opportunity (completed 12/8)3) GSS/BD was to facilitate a conference call with Peter Goebel, GSS IT Sourcing Portfolio Leader (set for 12/14)   In conversations with you, Jennifer Medcalf and myself this morning, several decisions on forward-looking strategy with HP/EBS were confirmed:Gerry Cashiola has been unable to take control of the process.  More importantly, despite numerous visits to Enron in which he has had overviews of Enron's products and services; met with Peter Goebel and his team on the GSS buy side, and participated in an Experience Enron tour, Gerry has been unable to define an HP business proposition.  The coordination between Cashiola (short term initiative) Morgridge (long term, 12-24 months) has remained unorganized.  These initiatives need to be developed separately.Clearly,  the conversations with HP need to be elevated to a more senior level so EBS can work with HP decision makers who can move the relationship forward at a strategic level.  As the relationship is developed at this strategic level, shorter term opportunities will crop up along the way.  But Gerry's short term plans will not be the focus of the EBS/HP relationship, rather a by-product.  To facilitate this process of elevating the relationship, Jennifer Medcalf and I are following up with Bill Lovejoy and Greg Pyle.  Lovejoy's boss is Dan Sytsma, VP of  HP's America's Central Region. In the conference call Thursday, 12/14 with Peter Goebel and HP regarding wireless initiatives, Peter will support the GSS/BD push for the HP/EBS initiative by reiterating the following two points:   a) Enron is already an HP customer; the onus is on HP  to move forward on the process of building a strategic  relationship  (IBM and Lexmark are only some of the HP competitors who could push them out of the running) b) HP's ability to bring the right people to the table will influence HP's business relationship process with Enron Patrick Tucker and Dale Clark could build their relationship with Bill Dwyer, Chief Architect e-Services Solutions, (met at the meeting 11/16) in the near term.  Perhaps, plan a visit to Cupertino, California to see Dwyer in person.  We look forward to continuing close collaboration with your team on this and other opportunities. Sarah-Joy HunterEnron CorporationGlobal Strategic Sourcing - Business Development#(713)-345-6541

body: fill in$ _____ per/share"Eva Pao" <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu> on 05/13/2001 02:39:23 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu>  what's my bid for what??psdon't no crap me.-----Original Message-----Sent: Sunday, May 13, 2001 4:30 PMno crap, what's your bid?"Eva Pao" <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu> on 05/13/2001 12:48:23 AMPlease respond to <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu>break even on info ass-symetry is 100%, any project above that level isprofitable to Pooks&Co.-----Original Message-----Sent: Sunday, May 13, 2001 1:04 AMFor extra credit....If the company is worth 150% more under management A rather than 50% more,does your answer change?"Eva Pao" <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu> on 05/11/2001 05:13:59 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu>will you do all of my homework?-----Original Message-----Sent: Friday, May 11, 2001 8:41 AMi'll pay a grand total of 0"Eva Pao" <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu> on 05/10/2001 05:15:59 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu> Please read the following problem very carefully, and write in a number atthe end.  You should be ready to defend your answer.  Only a number isallowed, not an algebraic equation.Acquiring a Company     In the following exercise you will represent Company A (the acquirer),which is currently considering acquiring Company T (the target) by means ofa tender offer.  You plan to tender in cash for 100% of Company T's sharesbut are unsure how high a price to offer.  The main complication is this:the value of Company T depends directly on the outcome of a major oilexploration project it is currently undertaking.  Indeed, the veryviabilityof Company T depends on the exploration outcome.  If the project fails, thecompany under current management will be worth nothing--$0/share.  But ifthe project succeeds, the value of the company under current managementcould be as high as $100/share.  All share values between $0 and $100 areconsidered equally likely.  By all estimates, the company will be worthconsiderably more in the hands of Company A than under current management.In fact, whatever the ultimate value under current management, the companywill be worth fifty percent more under the management of A than underCompany T.  If the project fails, the company is worth $0/share undereithermanagement.  If the exploration project generates a $50/share value undercurrent management, the value under Company A is $75/share.  Similarly, a$100/share value under Company T implies a $150/share value under CompanyA,and so on.     The board of directors of Company A has asked you to determine thepricethey should offer for Company T's shares.  This offer must be made now,before the outcome of the drilling project is known.  From all indications,Company T would be happy to be acquired by Company A, provided it is at aprofitable price.  Moreover, Company T wishes to avoid, at all cost, thepotential of a takeover bid by any other firm.  You expect Company T todelay a decision on your bid until the results of the project are in, thenaccept or reject your offer before the news of the drilling results reachesthe press.     Thus, you (Company A) will not know the results of the explorationprojectwhen submitting your price offer, but Company T will know the results whendeciding whether or not to accept your offer.  In addition, Company T willaccept any offer by Company A that is greater than the (per share) value ofthe company under current management.  Thus, if you offer $50/share, forinstance, Company T will accept if the value of the company to Company T isanything less than $50.     As the representative of Company A, you are deliberating over priceoffersin the range of $0/share (this is tantamount to making no offer at all) to$150/share.  What price offer per share would you tender for Company T'sstock?     $______ per/share

body: <email>Hi Dr. Patel,It was great to meet you at the conference last week and learn more about your fascinating research in nanotechnology and gene therapy. I was really impressed by your presentation and the potential impact your work could have on medicine.As I mentioned, I'm always looking for ways to bring cutting-edge science into the classroom and make it accessible to students. I think there could be a great opportunity to collaborate on some educational materials that showcase the real-world applications of your research. I'd love to brainstorm some ideas with you and see if we can come up with a project that would be engaging for high school students.Let me know if you'd be interested in chatting further. I'm happy to set up a call or meet for coffee if you're in the area.Best regards,Jessica
label: research

body: <email>Hi Emily,I hope you're doing well. I wanted to share some important information with you that I learned at the recent cybersecurity conference I attended. It appears that there's a new type of malware that has been targeting financial institutions, and I believe it could pose a significant threat to our clients.The malware, dubbed "FinStealer," is designed to infiltrate banking systems and steal sensitive customer data. It uses advanced evasion techniques to avoid detection by traditional antivirus software, making it particularly dangerous.I think we need to act quickly to develop a solution to protect our clients from this threat. Can we schedule a meeting to discuss this further and brainstorm some ideas?Let me know your availability.Best regards,John
label: research

body: <email>Dear Sarah,It's great to hear from you! I remember our conversation at the conference and I'm flattered that you thought of me for your article. I'd be more than happy to discuss my research and the potential applications of gravity manipulation.In fact, I recently published a paper on a new theory related to gravity manipulation that I think your readers would find fascinating. I could provide you with a copy of the paper and we could discuss it in more detail.Please let me know when would be a good time for you to chat. I'm looking forward to our collaboration!Best regards,Oliver
label: research

body: <email>Hey Michael,It's been great keeping in touch since we met at the conference in Philadelphia last year. I've been thinking a lot about our discussions on making complex topics more accessible to the general public. I believe our collaboration could lead to something truly unique, combining our expertise in oncology and colonial-era history.I have an idea for a project that explores the history of skin cancer treatments and how they've evolved over time. I think it would be fascinating to compare modern treatments with the practices used during the colonial era. Your insights into the historical context would be invaluable.Let me know if you're interested in discussing this further. I'd love to brainstorm some ideas and see if we can develop a proposal.Best regards,Emily

body: <email>Emily,It's always a pleasure to hear from you! Congratulations on this incredible fossil find - I can only imagine the excitement at your lab right now. I'd be delighted to take a look at the preliminary data and discuss how it might relate to our previous work.I'm available for a video call next Wednesday afternoon, if that works for you. Just send over the images and data whenever convenient, and I'll review them before our chat.This discovery could be a game-changer for our understanding of dinosaur biology and evolution. I'm eager to see where this leads and to collaborate with you once again.All the best,David

body: <email>Dear Dr. Thompson,It was great meeting you at the STEM education event last weekend. I really enjoyed our conversation about the importance of promoting science and mathematics to young students. As I mentioned, I'm a high school math teacher specializing in geometry, and I'm always looking for ways to make the subject more engaging and relevant for my students.I was wondering if you would be interested in keeping in touch and sharing ideas related to our respective fields. I'm particularly curious about how you use geometry and spatial reasoning in your research on renewable energy. I think there could be some interesting overlaps that we could explore together.Please let me know if you'd like to continue our discussion. I'd be happy to grab a coffee sometime and chat more.Best regards,Emily

I think that in my excitement and effort to get this meeting put together, I overlooked a few important details.  I will certainly do a better job next time!Thanks for the reminder!JYp.s. body: Chaz & Steve,I was able to review our recently completed conference call w/BMC with Jennifer Medcalf.  During the call, Bernie Goicoechea and Ann(e?) Munson expressed that during their last few months of interaction with Enron Net Works, they have attempted to understand the exact issues and concerns which Net Works has with regard to selection/use of BMC's products.  Bernie voiced that he hasn't been able to get more detail on the problems or nature of concerns that Net Works has, beyond what you and I know.  The BMC account team feels that without specifics, they cannot address the issues accurately or in a timely fashion.The Enron Net Works team has expressed concern that various BMC products are not Windows 2000 certified (at least, not the ones they are focused on, and not in writing).  Net Works also have some other concerns relative to the (Net Works) team's feelings that the BMC products (in some areas) "...haven't kept up with the industry", and that they (Net Works) have some residual issues with the BMC account support in general.  Bottom Line, expressed by Net Works, is that there is a low probability of their purchasing enough BMC software product this year to enable EBS to clinch its deal with BMC.You related Jim Crowder's suggestion related to the use of indemnification and liquidated damages clauses being implemented.  Jennifer and I discussed this situation, and our meetings with your team, in context.  We have a possible alternative for you to consider:  perhaps EBS might provide a hedge for Net Works in the form of "advance purchase" of BMC product.For example, EBS is poised to buy about $1 million worth of BMC software, but needs to show BMC a firm purchase commitment for about $3 million in total Enron purchases from BMC.  A way in which you could reach the $3 million mark with BMC; while also allowing the relationships between Net Works and BMC time to "click" might be this:  EBS buys all $3 million worth of BMC software, but $1 million is used to actually take product now, and the other $2 million is used as a "future purchases" fund, in which EBS buys, but does not take immediate delivery of, the (remaining $2 million worth of) current software...THEN, future Enron Net Works (and any other ENE business unit) purchases of BMC software would be executed such that EBS is paid, and the software is delivered from/by BMC.  That way, EBS gets its $2 million back, the other business units aren't spending any of today's dollars for product which they seem to have some concerns about (but they can get current/certified product when they need it in the future).  In addition, you secure the business with BMC right now.  I'm sure you could also figure out how to account for the time value of money in this, so that there is further leverage advantage to you.If all else fails, you may wish to consider something like this...In the meantime, we will continue along the current path and keep you posted on progress.Thanks,JeffJeff YoungfleshDirector, Business DevelopmentGlobal Strategic SourcingEnron Corp.333 Clay Street, 11th FloorHouston, TX 77002t:  713-345-5968f:  713-646-2450c:  713-410-6716

body: Jennifer:Mike Rabon had just forwarded to me this helpful synopsis of the opportunity with Kinko's as he sees it.  I would like to forward this on to James Thompson to assist him in targeting the right person for us to work with (and cc Mike Rabon).  Is this a good idea to forward on the e-mail or is it overkill given the e-mail I sent yesterday? Second, could I mention "Gary King" Mike Rabon's Kinko's contact in the e-mail?Thanks for your suggestion!  SJMr. Thompson:Here are several "touchpoints" identified by Mike Rabon, the Enron Broadband Services originator, which may facilitate your finding the appropriate broadband solutions architect at Kinko's.  You may recall having met Mike Rabon in the October 6th meeting. Kinko's has an IP network today with access to all branches.  Kinko's had expressed the need to add more hubs to that network and make some changes to it in the spring 2001 time frame.  Enron's goal would be to make a needs assessment for the desired structure that Kinko's would like to see as it pertains to:Near term network planning.IP Transport - Capacity requirements for Mbps, and burst potential.IP Transit - Capacity requirements and current contract usage for internet transit. Kinkos.com in particular has a high potential for IP transit capacity.Storage - As the hubs and branch numbers grow, there may be a need for managed storage. Enron's solution will reduce, or eliminate the need to buy storage devices. Mike Rabon would like to speak with someone at Kinko's about your storage strategy and growth.Collocation - There is a substantial opportunity for Enron to provide the actual space to be used for the hubs, as well as the IP transport from the hubs.Interactive Video - Enron's IPNet Connect product will allow high quality H.323 video conferencing at bandwidths well above 768K. Utilizing the Enron IPNet Connect network installed to branches can allow video costs to be significantly reduced, and allow much higher video quality.  Enron's utilization of IP precedence will allow business traffic, internet traffic and video traffic to traverse the same network.  Mike Rabon would like to speak to the Video Conferencing product manager.Risk Management - Enron's expertise in Risk Management needs to be communicated to the proper person.

body: Although I would prefer to see the counterparty name for failed transactions, it is not of great importance and I certainly understand a third party system not supplying us with that info.Andy Zipper@ENRON07/31/2000 01:51 PM  John,As you are probably aware we did a click through deal with Houston Street, whereby EOL prices would be posted on their platform. The initial thought was that this would be transparent to the trading desks; they wouldn't care whether the trade came from Houston Street, True Quote or EOL (although we could make the platform name available to you if you so desired.) This still will be the case except for one problem: Houston Street does not want us to reveal the counterparty name to the trader in the event of a failed transaction. I don't know whether this is an issue for you or not, but I would like to know. We will probably run into this issue with any platform we deal with for obvious anonymity reasons. I would really appreciate your thoughts/concerns.-Andy

body: <email>Hi Margaret,It was such a pleasure to meet you at the Religion, Culture, and the Environment conference last week. I really enjoyed your presentation on the environmental stewardship mandate in the Geneva Bible and its influence on American history. As someone who teaches and writes about environmental ethics from a more secular perspective, I found your talk really fascinating and thought-provoking.I would love to continue our conversation about the intersections of religion, philosophy, and environmental responsibility. I'm curious to hear more about your perspective on the role of faith communities in addressing environmental issues today. Do you see this as an important priority for your church and denominational community?I'd also be happy to share more about my work on eco-feminism and animal rights if you're interested. I think there could be some interesting parallels and points of connection with your own scholarship, even though we're coming from quite different angles.Let me know if you'd like to continue the conversation via email or even set up a time to chat by phone or video. body: Our natural gas business continues to benefit from effective account management and resource allocation focused on identifying and responding to the needs of our varied customers.  In order to keep our organization optimally structured and to facilitate additional growth, we are making the following changes:Producer/Wellhead Group The current mid-market, origination and wellhead pricing activity currently within the Central and Eastern Gas Regions will be consolidated with the Derivatives group under Fred Lagrasta.  This will create a single business unit focused upon the needs of the producing industry within the Eastern U.S.  The producer focus in the Western U.S. and Texas will remain unchanged reporting  to Mark Whitt and Brian Redmond respectively.Strategic Asset  DevelopmentLaura Luce will move from her role in the Central Region to lead an effort focused strictly on identifying and entering into long-term strategic arrangements within the Central and Eastern Regions.  This initiative will focus on a limited number of selected markets that provide strategic opportunities for partnering in asset development, asset management and optimization.  This effort will continue to work very closely with the regional leads.Central Origination and Mid-MarketFrank Vickers will continue his current role in the Eastern Region and will assume the leadership role for Mid-Market and Origination activity in the Central Region.  There will be no changes to the West and Texas Origination groups headed respectively by Barry Tycholiz and Brian Redmond. Please join us in congratulating Fred, Laura and Frank in their new roles.Louise & John
