body: Pam,Can you help with below?David -----Original Message-----Sent:	Monday, November 26, 2001 11:18 AMDavid,For clarity, wherever you cite Section 6.2 in your response I assume you mean Section 6.3.  Your response does not address the key points upon which I based my interpretation of the plan.  The beginning of Section 6.3 states "Notwithstanding any other provision of the plan?".   This implies that Section 6.3 contains the complete rules for an accelerated distribution.  I disagree with your translation of "a single sum distribution" as meaning all at once instead of a single amount.  I would like to meet to discuss or appeal to Greg W. or John L.   In addition, your response does not address Section 7.1.  This appears to be the relevant section if the PSA is to be paid in shares.  Additionally the Q & A section in the plan brochure (pg. 8) works through an example of adjusting the number of shares to retain a certain dollar value.  This is the methodology described in Section 7.1.Tom Martin and Scott Neal share the above concerns.  Please advise of a convenient time we can all meet to discuss further.Phillip   -----Original Message-----Sent:	Monday, November 26, 2001 8:31 AMCc:	Whalley, Greg; Joyce, MaryFor purposes of an accelerated distribution from the PSA,  a "single sum distribution," in Section 6.2 means that a PSA account is distributed all at once, as distinguished from another form of payout as may have been selected by a participant in his or her deferral agreement.  Section 6.2 is clear in that the account balance shall be determined as of the last day of the month preceding the date on which the Committee receives the written request of the Participant.  A PSA account balance is reflected in shares of stock since the form of distribution is shares of stock.Additionally, any portion of a PSA balance attributable to deferral of restricted stock is administered under Sections 3.5 and 3.6 and Exhibit A of the Plan. This section is applicable now as we are accelerating the distribution of PSA balances created with deferrals of restricted stock.  The Plan indicates that upon death, disability, retirement or termination, the share units are converted to shares which are issued to the executive according to the payment election made by the executive at the time of the deferral election.        Therefore the distribution you will receive in shares is correct and we do not agree with your interpretation of the plan.

body: <email>Dear Emily,Thank you for reaching out! I enjoyed our conversation at the event as well. I'm always eager to connect with fellow educators and professionals who are passionate about STEM.I would definitely be interested in keeping in touch and exploring the intersections between our work. In fact, I recently published a paper on a new catalyst that improves the efficiency of solar cells, and I think some of the concepts could be visualized using geometric principles. I'd be curious to hear your thoughts on that.I'm also intrigued by the idea of collaborating on a project related to STEM education. If you have any ideas or opportunities in mind, please let me know. I'd be happy to contribute my expertise in any way I can.I'm looking forward to continuing our discussion. Let's plan to grab that coffee soon!Best regards,Michael

body: <email>Dear Alex,I hope this email finds you well. I've been thinking about our discussion at the conference and I believe your expertise in immune response could greatly benefit my current study on radiation and vaccine efficacy.I'm particularly interested in your insights on how radiation might affect the immunogenicity of vaccine candidates. If you're open to it, I'd like to schedule a call to discuss potential collaboration on this project.Please let me know your availability in the coming weeks. I look forward to working with you.Best regards,Dr. Emily Chen

body: <email>Emily,I think your lesson plan outline sounds great! Starting with the historical context and then introducing the Enigma machine and its significance is a good way to engage the students and provide them with the necessary background information.I can definitely create some encrypted messages for the students to decipher using modular arithmetic and congruences. We can even make it a competition or a team activity to see who can crack the code first!One suggestion I have is to maybe include a brief explanation of how the Enigma machine works and its inner workings. I think the students would find it interesting to see the actual machine and understand the mechanical and mathematical principles behind it.Let me know if you need any help with the historical aspects of the lesson plan as well. I'd be happy to assist in any way I can.Best,Alex
label: research

body: <email>Emily,Thank you so much for your generous offer! The resources you've put together sound perfect for helping my students grasp the importance of the Silk Road. I'm particularly excited about the curriculum guide, as it will provide a structured way for my students to explore the topic.I'd love to schedule a time for you to come to my classroom and give a brief presentation on the Silk Road, perhaps touching on some key aspects that you think will be most relevant to the exhibit. This would really help set the stage for their visit and get them excited about what they'll be seeing.Additionally, I've been thinking more about incorporating mindfulness and meditation practices into my teaching, as we discussed before. Do you have any suggestions for how I could tie these practices into our study of the Silk Road? I think it could be a powerful way to help my students connect with the material on a deeper level.Thanks again for all your support. I'm looking forward to collaborating with you on this project!Best,Michael Thompson5th Grade Social Studies TeacherRiverview Elementary School
label: research

body: <email>Jordan,I'm glad the timing works for you and your students. I'll see you on Tuesday!Your lesson plan on the different roles in space missions sounds fantastic. I'd be happy to share my perspective and discuss how amateur astronomers can contribute to the space exploration community. In fact, I've been involved in a few citizen science projects where amateur astronomers collaborate with professional researchers to analyze data and make discoveries. I think this could be a great way to show your students that they don't have to be professional scientists to make a difference in the field.I'll also share some stories about the incredible women and men who work on missions like Juno, highlighting the diverse backgrounds and skill sets that come together to make these missions possible. I think this could help your students see themselves in these roles and inspire them to pursue their passions in STEM.If you're interested, I could also bring my telescope to school one evening and give your students a hands-on experience observing the night sky. It would be a great way to cap off our discussion and give them a tangible connection to the wonders of space.Let me know what you think about these ideas, and if there's anything else I can do to support your lesson plan.Best,Alex
label: research

body: <email>Hi Liam,I hope you're doing well. I wanted to reach out to you about a new course I'm developing for the "Languages and Cultures" program. The course will explore the intersection of animal rights and language, and I think your expertise in sociolinguistics could help make it even more comprehensive.I was also thrilled to hear that we'll be giving a joint presentation at the upcoming conference. I believe this could be a great opportunity to showcase our interdisciplinary collaboration and share our findings with the academic community.Would you be available for a meeting next week to discuss these topics further? I'd love to get your input and brainstorm some ideas together.Best regards,Emily

Black/HOU/ECT@ECT, Amy Cooper/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kay Chapman/HOU/ECT@ECT This is a reminder !!!  If you haven't taken the time to update your GIS information, please do so.  It is essential that this function be performed as soon as possible. Please read the following memo sent to you a few days ago and if you have any questions regarding this request, please feel free to call Ted Bland @ 3-5275.With Enron's rapid growth we need to maintain an ability to move employees between operating companies and new ventures.  To do this it is essential to have one process that will enable us to collect , update and retain employee data.  In the spirit of One Enron, and building on the success of the year-end Global VP/MD Performance Review Process, the  Enron VP/MD PRC requests that all Enron Vice Presidents and Managing Directors update their profiles. Current responsibilities, employment history, skills and education need to be completed  via the HR Global Information System.  HRGIS is accessible via the HRWEB home page on the intranet.  Just go to hrweb.enron.com and look for the HRGIS link.  Or just type eglobal.enron.com on the command line of your browser.The target date by which to update these profiles is 7 July.  If you would like to have a hard copy of a template that could be filled out and returned for input, or If you need any assistance with the HRGIS application please contact Kathy Schultea at x33841.  Your  timely response to this request is greatly appreciated.   Thanks,Dave

body: <email>Hi Daniel,I hope you're having a great week so far! I wanted to touch base with you regarding our multicultural storybook project. The students have been making fantastic progress on their pages, and I'm thrilled with the diversity of cultures and stories they've chosen to represent.I've been thinking about the layout of the storybook and how we can best showcase each student's work. Do you have any thoughts or suggestions? I'd love to hear your ideas!Also, have you had a chance to finalize the date and time for our multicultural music and storytelling event? I want to make sure we give our students and their families enough notice to plan accordingly.Looking forward to hearing back from you and continuing to collaborate on this exciting project!Best regards,Samantha

body: <email>Dear Emily,I'm glad to hear that you and your students are eager to explore the resources I'll be sharing. Understanding the genetic factors behind disease susceptibility and resistance is indeed a crucial aspect of our work, and I'm happy to provide more information on that topic.The project idea you described sounds fantastic. I'll be sure to send over a dataset that your students can work with to create their visualizations. I'm confident that their work will help make our research more accessible to a wider audience.As for the guest lecture, the week of May 10th works perfectly with my schedule. I'll be happy to join your class via webinar at 10:00 AM CST on a date that suits you best. Please let me know which day within that week would be most convenient for you and your students.Regarding the virtual science fair, I would be delighted to be your keynote speaker. It's an honor to be considered, and I'm always eager to engage with the next generation of scientists. I look forward to discussing the details with your organizing committee.Thank you once again for reaching out and for your commitment to providing your students with valuable learning experiences. I'm excited to collaborate with you and your class, and I'm confident that this partnership will be mutually beneficial.Best regards,Michael Johnson, PhDDepartment of MathematicsUniversity of South Africa
label: research

body: <email>Hey Jordan,I hope this email finds you well! I remember you mentioned that you were planning a unit on space exploration for your students. As promised, I've compiled some resources that you might find useful for your lesson plans.I've attached a folder containing the latest images and data from our observations of Jupiter and its moons, particularly Io. You'll find high-resolution images, detailed maps, and some fascinating information about the unique geological features and volcanism on Io. I've also included a few articles and research papers that I thought might be accessible and engaging for your students.Please feel free to use these materials in any way that suits your needs. If you have any questions or need further clarification on any of the content, just let me know. I'm always happy to help!Best regards,Alex
label: research

body: <email>Dear Elena,Thank you for reaching out, and apologies for the delayed response. Your research on the Alaska Purchase and its connection to the philosophical ideas of the time is fascinating. I would be delighted to discuss this further and explore the potential for collaboration.I believe that the works of Spinoza, Hobbes, and Machiavelli could indeed have had a significant influence on the decision-making processes of the key figures involved in the purchase. Spinoza's ideas on the nature of the state and the role of reason in politics, Hobbes' concept of the social contract, and Machiavelli's pragmatic approach to power dynamics could all provide valuable insights into the motivations and strategies employed by the Russian and American negotiators.I have a few resources that might be helpful for your research, and I would be happy to share them with you. Additionally, I think that our collaboration could lead to a compelling joint paper that explores the intersection of philosophy and history in this specific context. We could potentially present our findings at the upcoming interdisciplinary conference on "Philosophy and History: Reexamining the Past Through Multiple Lenses."Please let me know your thoughts on this proposal, and if you're available for a meeting to discuss the project further.Best regards,David Spinelli

The grant committee was impressed with our proposal and the potential impact our program could have on students with and without disabilities.However, now that we're in the implementation phase, we're running into some scheduling conflicts. It's been difficult to find a time when both our schools can have students available for the program. I was wondering if you had any ideas for how we could work around this issue.Another challenge we're facing is finding volunteers to help with the program. We need people who are knowledgeable about adaptive sports and can assist our students during practices and games. Do you have any suggestions for where we could find reliable volunteers?I know we've got a lot to figure out, but I'm confident that we can make this program a success. body: <email>Dear Dr. Klein,I am thrilled to hear that you are as enthusiastic about our potential collaboration as I am. I completely agree that our respective fields can offer unique and valuable perspectives on the concept of resilience in the face of catastrophic events.As for our video conference call, I would be available next Tuesday, April 12th, at 10:00 AM my time (Pacific Daylight Time). If this works for you, please let me know, and I will send you a meeting invite with the video conferencing details.In the meantime, I have been thinking about the conference organizers' request for a proposal for a joint session at next year's conference. I believe that our paper on resilience could form the basis for an engaging and thought-provoking session. We could explore the parallels between geological and historical cataclysmic events and how humans have adapted and persevered in the face of these challenges. We could also discuss the implications of our findings for contemporary society and the challenges we face today.I would love to hear your thoughts on this idea and any suggestions you may have for the joint session proposal. Please feel free to share any other ideas or topics you think would be worth exploring in our collaboration.I look forward to our call next week and to further discussing our exciting collaboration.Best regards,Dr. Emily Thompson

body: ---------------------- 04:57 PM ---------------------------"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AMPlease respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com> "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> Enclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austinthat we told you about.  As you can tell from the proforma this projectshould produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.This is especially attractive when the project is in a market as strong asAustin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range forthis market.  This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that wehave uncovered to date in the Austin market.The project does have approved zoning and will only require a site plan.  Asit is in the "Smart Growth Corridor" area designated by the City of Austinfor preferred development, this will be fast tracked and should be completein less than 6 months.  Additionally, many of the current and more severewater treatment ordinances have been waived.  I have estimated the lotimprovement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in NorthAustin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and streetwidening.  Even though this property is not likely to require streetwidening and will have less of a detention/retention and filtration pondrequirement, I used this data to be cautious. The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is notexpected to impact sales significantly.  Other projects have been quitesuccessful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as theadjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.As with most infill projects, the quality of the surrounding neighborhoodsis uneven.  We have included a fence around the entire property, but mayonly put it on Westgate and Cameron Loop.  Gated communities are farpreferred so this is a good idea for both screening and current buyerpreferences.The seller accepted our offer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 andan extended escrow.  This will enable us to probably obtain an approved siteplan before closing on the contract, which will mean that we can close intoan A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.This analysis shows your investment at $700,000 for a 50% interest in theprofits of the project.  As we discussed in San Marcos, we can also discusshaving you invest only in the lots, sell the lots to the construction entitywith your profit in the lot.  I believe this would facilitate the use of a1031 Exchange of the proceeds from this deal into another project that is arental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would thenbe the equity for that project.  You would need to discuss this with anexchange expert first.  Larry Lewter knows an expert in the field in SanAntonio if you do not know anyone.I will send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,by Airborne Express today for Saturday delivery.Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want toschedule a tour of the site and the area.  Please get back to me as soon asyour schedule permits regarding the site visit and feel free to call at anytime.  You can reach me over the weekend and in the evening at either512-338-1119 or 512-338-1110.  My cell phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is512-338-1103.   I look forward to hearing from you and to working with youon this project that is sure to be a major winner.I regret that it took so long to get back to you, but we had some unusualevents these past few weeks.  A small freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpgdowndrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.One of these units had just had the roof decked with the siding scheduled tostart the next day.  The severe downdraft hitting the decked roof was enoughto knock it down.  The City shut down the project for a week and it tookanother week to get every thing back on tract. body: John,Following up on yesterday, there are two additional considerations. First, with regard to the idea of curtailing gas input at the Topock liquefaction plant, the pipeline bottleneck is actually downstream of the plant, so that wouldn't help. Second, it seems there are more of these "portable pipeline" units floating around than I thought. Besides the inoperable unit in Amarillo, both Transgas (in Massachusetts) and Minnigasco may have at least one. Moreover, PG&E has one at the end of a long lateral line on its system just south of Sacramento. Apparently it uses it mostly to augment linepack. The specs of that unit are about 4 times higher than the Amarillo one: it puts out 400,000 cubic feet/hour (about 9.6 mmcf/d or almost one contract) at 150 psi. As I said yesterday, these units are the only way that you could get gas into the pipeline system in California. This information I got from Jeff Beale, who runs CH-IV, a small-scale LNG consultant. He said that he'd had some similar calls about LNG, and also that he'd be willing to help Enron source equipment if we were really interested in looking further into transporting LNG into California. Assuming that we could get a few "portable pipelines" and some trucks, there are five liquefaction plants that could most conveniently supply LNG:Location Owner  Liquefaction Capacity (gal/day)  Capacity (mmcf/d) Storage (gal) Storage (mmcf)Topock, AZ ElPaso/ALT 90,000      7.4   100,000  8.2LaPlata, CO Williams 20,000     1.64   100,000  8.2Sacramento   57,600     4.72   132,000  10.8LaBarge, WY Exxon  60,000     4.92      Evanston, WY Amoco  95,000     7.8   100,000  8.2Totals         26.48Whether these plants have spare LNG to sell us is another question. The Sacramento plant, which I mentioned yesterday, is supposedly dedicated to providing methane for laboratory purposes. The others may have contracts with LNG fleet owners. I'll check back with you later today about the outcome of your meeting.

body: <email>Hi Dr. Carlisle,It was such a pleasure meeting you at the World Stamp Show last week. I really enjoyed our conversation about the history of postal services and philately. Your presentation on the impact of the postal system on 19th-century communication was fascinating!I hope you had a smooth journey back to London. The conference was quite an experience, wasn't it? I've been to a few of these events before, but this one was by far the largest and most impressive.I'd love to stay in touch and perhaps collaborate on some research projects in the future. If you come across any interesting stamps or postal history artifacts from your side of the pond, please do let me know. I'm always on the lookout for new additions to my collection.Best regards,James

body: I think you need to check your AGA model.  7.2 bcf/d seems awfully high.  That's saying that had gas been at $2.5, the AGA for the week would have been 151.  Look at the AGA history for last week, this week and next week.   94 95 96 97 98 99 00 01 3rd week of Feb  -64 -46 -64 -63 -77 -97 -136 -814th week of Feb  -132 -118 -62 -76 -47 -128 -74 -101 1st week of Mar  -27 -132 -118 -57 -54 -69 -37 ??Do you really think the # would have been 151 with no demand destruction?  It wasn't even really cold.  That would have been the highest AGA # of the three weeks by 15 bcf.  Our guys are thinking 4.5 bcf/d.  Pira is saying that Feb as a whole averages 3.5-4 bcf/d. That's just destruction and does not include new production, if any.  Further Pira estimates that March destruction will be about half of Feb.  Assuming that gets to equilibrium:  2 bcf/d demand destruction, 2 bcf/d more production, 2 bcf/d more gas generation demand.  Start with a 400 b deficit and 200 injection days gets you to flat against last years storage in current price environment.   I think we are fairly priced fundamentally, but with huge customer imbalance for hedging from buy side, surprises in the market right now are to the upside in my view.  Course hard to imagine $6 for J.   Just sell vol.slafontaine@globalp.com on 03/02/2001 10:54:14 AM  my next aga number is 75-sllitely more than pira and assumes 7.2 bcf/d y on ys&d swing-the higher prices now the uglier it'll be later.contmaplating buying some 4.00 puts for lat 2nd q or early 3q for a few pennies.so whaen we go above last years stx in may!!beleive it or not pero been worse chop fest than gas-all i know is going tosteamboat co skiing next wed-sunday with mans refined prod groups next week sotaking postion down to the stuff i really like, dont have to worry too muchabout.John.Arnold@enron.com on 03/02/2001 11:44:50 AMFax to:i think this is the biggest chopfest in nat gas history.  scale up seller,scale down buyer.reviewing my aga model and assumptions later today.  i'll see if i have anynew inspirations.slafontaine@globalp.com on 03/02/2001 10:25:45 AMhe will be if we cut him off for a week i bet he gets some inspiration.have agood weekdn. any view here? i think short term range stuff-med-longer termyouknow what i think.  sprds/front to backs range-bear em at -2 bull em at -5 till they goprompt.John.Arnold@enron.com on 03/02/2001 11:22:30 AMFax to:ok.i would not describe him as the hardest working man in the energy business.slafontaine@globalp.com on 03/02/2001 08:54:44 AMi say we make a pact, next time silver man calls in sick on a friday afteratypical nite out you and i cut him off for the entire next week. deal?

body: ---------------------- 01:32 PM ---------------------------   				  Phillip--I've noticed one thing on your intra-month transport p&l that looks strange to me.  Remember that I do not know the Northwest at all, so this may not be an issue, but I'll point it out and let you decide.  Let me know if this is O.K. as is, so I'll know to ignore it in the future.  Also, if you want me to get with Kim and the Sitara people to change the mapping, let me know and I'll take care of it..On PG&E NW, it appears that PGEN Kingsgate is mapped to a Malin Citygate curve instead of a Kingsgate curve, resulting in a total transport loss of $235,019.   (If the mapping were changed, it should just reallocate p&l--not change your overall p&l.)  Maybe there is a reason for this mapping or maybe it affects something else somewhere that I am not seeing, but anyway, here are the Deal #'s, paths and p&l impacts of each.  139195  From Kingsgate to Malin     ($182,030)  139196 From Kingsgate to PGEN/Tuscarora   ($    4,024)  139197  From Kingsgate to PGEN Malin    ($    8,271)  231321  From Kingsgate to Malin     ($  38,705)  153771 From Kingsgate to Stanfield    ($     1,988) Suggested fix:  Change PGEN Kingsgate mapping from GDP-Malin Citygate to GDP-Kingsgate. Clay Basin storage--this is really a FYI more than anything else--I see five different tickets in Sitara for Clay Basin activity--one appears to be for withdrawals and the other four are injections.  Clay Basin is valued as a Questar curve, which is substantially below NWPL points.  What this means is that any time you are injecting gas, these tickets will show transport losses; each time you are withdrawing, you will show big gains on transport.  I'm not sure of the best way to handle this since we don't really have a systematic Sitara way of handling storage deals.  In an ideal world, it seems that you would map it the way you have it today, but during injection times, the transport cost would pass through as storage costs.  Anyway, here's the detail on the tickets just for your info, plus I noticed three days where it appears we were both withdrawing and injecting from Clay Basin.  There may be an operational reason why this occurred that I'm not aware of, and the dollar impact is very small, but I thought I'd bring it to your attention just in case there's something you want to do about it.  The columns below show the volumes under each ticket and the p&L associated with each.  Deal #  251327                  159540                   265229         106300   201756P&L  $29,503                ($15,960)                ($3,199)          ($2,769)   ($273)Rec:   Ques/Clay Basin/0184   NWPL/Opal 543  NWPL/Opal   Sumas      NWPL/S of Gr RvrDel:   NWPL/S of Green River/Clay   Ques/Clay Basin/0852   Ques/Clay Basin/0852   Ques/Clay Basin    Ques/Clay Basin1        329       8,7382     1,5003         2,974    11,3624         6,741    12,349       1,4395       19,052          3,1839            33313  30,863       2,68014  30,451    15  35,226    16         6,979              235 17  17,464     18    9,294     20  10,796          77121  17,930     22  10,667     23       14,415          9,07625  23,934       8,69526     3,284     27         1,97628     1,751     29     1,591     30  20,242

body: Certainly encourage CSFP to transact all volumes with us.  If they shop the deal, everyone will front-run the volumes and they won't get a good price on the deal.  Financial deals settle 5 days after the index has been published.  Physical deals settle much later.   My understanding is this is a financial deal.   				 Per Sekse/NY/ECT@ECT, Caroline Abramo/Corp/Enron@Enron, John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sara Shackleton/HOU/ECT@ECT, William S Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT The New York office has been speaking to Credit Suisse First Boston for roughly 6 months about a producer hedging deal that is part of a strucutured deal they're putting together. It now looks as if it will get done in the next 3 weeks-1 month so we want to get all the necessary credit issues taken care of. In brief, the deal is a fixed price one, basis TCO (67% of the volumes) and CNG (33%) with a fixed price Nymex component as well. It will settle against the Inside FERC indices for both locations. The term of the deal is from December, 2000 to December 2012. The volumes decline throughout the term from roughly 22,000 mmBtu/d to 13,000 mmBtu/d. The average daily nominal volume is 17,000 mmBtu/d. As I understand it, these volumes are about 65% of the producers' total volumes. I've attached a spreadsheet to this message with more details. There are a couple of contractual and credit issues that CSFB wants to clarify. First, there is a question of the monthly cash settlement. CSFB would like payment to take place on the fifteenth of the month following the date both the floating and fixed prices are known. As I understand it,  for the December settlement, which would be known in early December, cash payment would take place on February 15, 2000. Second, there is a question of a parent guarantee from Enron Corp. Apparently, there is an existing credit arrangement in place between ENA and Credit Suisse First Boston International - the same counterparty that we would be dealing with here - that has a $15 million guarantee from Enron Corp. CSFB would like to increase this guarantee to at least $100 million. (CSFB already has an unlimited guarantee from Enron Corp. for a deal they've done with us in Europe so in their opinion it should not be an issue).  There is another minor issue involving centralizing credit discussions with the aim of securing a similar credit arrangement for CSFB's dealings with EnronCredit.com - which may be an issue for London rather than Houston. However, CSFB agreed that this was a secondary issue in relation to this transaction.CSFB would like to do the entire deal through us, rather than having to split it among one or more counterparties. Per, Caroline Abramo, and I are meeting with Paul tomorrow to discuss various credit issues, including this one. Ideally, CSFB would like to have a good idea of where they stand by the end of this week. Please let me know if you have any questions or suggestions.Regards,Russ

body: <email>Hi Sarah,Thanks for sending over the latest draft of the project proposal. I've reviewed it and think you've done an excellent job outlining our goals and the potential impact of the game-based learning tool.Regarding the game mechanics, I was thinking about incorporating some sort of reward system where children earn points or badges for completing certain tasks or reaching milestones in their hearing management. This could help motivate them to stay engaged with the game and reinforce positive habits.I'd also like to explore ways to make the game adaptive, so that it can adjust the difficulty level based on the child's progress and individual needs. This could help ensure that the game remains challenging and effective for a wide range of children with different abilities and learning styles.Let me know what you think about these ideas, and if you have any other suggestions for making the game as effective and engaging as possible.Best,Michael
label: research

body: <email>Liam,I'm thrilled to report that our grant proposal has been accepted! This is a huge step forward for our research and a testament to the strong case we made for the importance of studying the long-term impacts of catastrophic geological events.I've been in touch with my department head, and they are fully supportive of this collaboration. We can start making arrangements for me to visit your field site at Mount Etna and for you to come to Mount Rainier. I think being able to collect data and samples together will be invaluable for our study.In the meantime, I'll start working on the preliminary data analysis from the papers we've exchanged. I have a few ideas for how we can structure our comparative analysis, which I'd love to run by you.Thank you for being such a wonderful collaborator and friend throughout this process. I have no doubt that our work together will lead to important discoveries and advancements in our field.Can't wait to see you in person soon!Best,Sophia

body: To "Outstanding" Analysts and Associates:I  am writing to inform of a possible opening on the natural gas derivatives trading desk.  It is an opportunity to work on one of the most profitable and demanding groups within Enron, as well as one of the largest financial commodity trading desks worldwide.  I envision the role as performing analysis initially, to grasp an understanding of gas fundamentals and become more familiar with the trading environment, and leading to a junior trading role.  Upside potential is limitless for the right person.Candidates for the role need to possess the following qualities:1. Have been ranked as outstanding on previous yearend reviews.2. Excellent math and quantitative skills.  Candidates should have 700+ math SAT and/or 700+ GMAT3. Basic understanding of economics including pricing differences under monopolistic and competitive market scenarios.4. Ability to work under intense pressure.  If you are interested please email with interest and attach a resume.  Do not call.John ArnoldVice President of Gas Derivatives Trading

body: ---------------------- 04:35 PM ---------------------------"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AMPlease respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com> "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> Enclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austinthat we told you about.  As you can tell from the proforma this projectshould produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.This is especially attractive when the project is in a market as strong asAustin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range forthis market.  This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that wehave uncovered to date in the Austin market.The project does have approved zoning and will only require a site plan.  Asit is in the "Smart Growth Corridor" area designated by the City of Austinfor preferred development, this will be fast tracked and should be completein less than 6 months.  Additionally, many of the current and more severewater treatment ordinances have been waived.  I have estimated the lotimprovement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in NorthAustin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and streetwidening.  Even though this property is not likely to require streetwidening and will have less of a detention/retention and filtration pondrequirement, I used this data to be cautious. The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is notexpected to impact sales significantly.  Other projects have been quitesuccessful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as theadjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.As with most infill projects, the quality of the surrounding neighborhoodsis uneven.  We have included a fence around the entire property, but mayonly put it on Westgate and Cameron Loop.  Gated communities are farpreferred so this is a good idea for both screening and current buyerpreferences.The seller accepted our offer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 andan extended escrow.  This will enable us to probably obtain an approved siteplan before closing on the contract, which will mean that we can close intoan A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.This analysis shows your investment at $700,000 for a 50% interest in theprofits of the project.  As we discussed in San Marcos, we can also discusshaving you invest only in the lots, sell the lots to the construction entitywith your profit in the lot.  I believe this would facilitate the use of a1031 Exchange of the proceeds from this deal into another project that is arental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would thenbe the equity for that project.  You would need to discuss this with anexchange expert first.  Larry Lewter knows an expert in the field in SanAntonio if you do not know anyone.I will send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,by Airborne Express today for Saturday delivery.Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want toschedule a tour of the site and the area.  Please get back to me as soon asyour schedule permits regarding the site visit and feel free to call at anytime.  You can reach me over the weekend and in the evening at either512-338-1119 or 512-338-1110.  My cell phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is512-338-1103.   I look forward to hearing from you and to working with youon this project that is sure to be a major winner.I regret that it took so long to get back to you, but we had some unusualevents these past few weeks.  A small freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpgdowndrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.One of these units had just had the roof decked with the siding scheduled tostart the next day.  The severe downdraft hitting the decked roof was enoughto knock it down.  The City shut down the project for a week and it tookanother week to get every thing back on tract.  Then last week I had to takemy wife  to emergency.  She has a bulge in the material between the vertebrain her spine and it causes her extreme pain and has kept her bedridden thispast week..  There is nothing like having your wife incapacitated to realizethe enormous number of things she does everyday.   Fortunately, it looks asif she will be ok in the long run.George W. RichardsCreekside Builders, LLC - Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls

body: <email>Dr. Thompson,Thank you for your prompt response and your kind words. I'm glad you agree about the conference. I'll keep an eye out for your feedback on the conclusion.In the meantime, I'll start preparing a brief outline for our presentation, focusing on the key points of our argument and the most significant insights we've uncovered. I'll share it with you as soon as it's ready for your input.Once again, thank you for your guidance and support throughout this project. I've learned so much from our collaboration, and I'm excited to see where this research leads us in the future.Best,Emily

body: <email>Daniel,I'd be happy to take a look at your project outline! It sounds like a fascinating angle to explore. Please feel free to send it my way whenever you're ready.As for "sus," I've definitely heard it used by my students. It's interesting to see how quickly these terms spread across different age groups and regions. I wonder if social media is the main driver or if there are other factors at play.I look forward to seeing your outline and discussing this further!Best,Emily

body: <email>Hi Emily,Thanks for the update! I'm glad to hear that the meeting with the publisher went well. I'll take a look at the magnetic storage chapter and provide my feedback by the end of the week.I've been doing some research on the impact of cloud computing on data storage and preservation, and I think it would make for an interesting chapter. I can start working on an outline if you'd like.Also, I wanted to remind you that we have a podcast recording scheduled for next Tuesday. The topic is "The Future of Data Storage: Trends and Predictions." Let me know if you have any ideas for discussion points or potential interviewees.Looking forward to your thoughts on the cloud computing chapter idea!Best,Alex

body: <email>Hi Sam,Thanks for sharing that article! I've been swamped with field work lately, but I'm always eager to discuss spider communication strategies. It's fascinating how Salticids have evolved such complex chemical mimicry alongside their visual displays. In orb weavers, we see a lot of chemical communication in courtship and web-building, but nothing quite as elaborate as what you're describing.I'd love to collaborate on a paper exploring the parallels and differences between chemical communication in jumping spiders and orb weavers. Maybe we could even get some funding to do a comparative study?I'm free to chat next week if you want to brainstorm ideas.Cheers,Ethan
label: research

body: <email>Dear Anjali,Thank you for reaching out and offering to be a guest lecturer for our study abroad program in Hyderabad. We are excited about the opportunity to have you share your expertise on the Telangana movement with our students.Your insights will be invaluable in helping our students understand the historical and cultural context of the region they will be studying. We would be happy to schedule your lecture for the second week of the program, which will be in mid-June. Please let me know if this works for you.Additionally, we would like to invite you to join us for a guided tour of some of the archaeological sites in the area. Your knowledge of the region's history would greatly enhance our students' experience.Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns. We look forward to working with you and ensuring our students have a memorable and educational experience in Hyderabad.Best regards,Dr. Ethan Roberts

body: <email>Hey Liam,I hope you're doing well and enjoying your new job at Genetech. It's been a while since we last touched base, and I wanted to reach out because I could really use your help with something.I've been awarded a grant to develop a new genetics curriculum for high schools in our district, and I'm feeling both excited and overwhelmed by the task. I want to create something that's engaging and meaningful for students, but I also want to make sure it's up-to-date with the latest developments in the field.I was wondering if you'd be willing to take a look at what I have so far and provide some feedback? I'd be especially interested in any insights you might have about the current state of genetics research and how it could be incorporated into the curriculum.Let me know if you have any time in the next few weeks to chat or meet up. I'd be happy to treat you to coffee or lunch in exchange for your expertise!Best,Jessica
label: research

body: <email>Hi Michael,I hope you're doing well. I'm reaching out to you because I'm developing a new educational workshop series on stress management and its impact on gut health. I think this would be a great opportunity for us to collaborate and incorporate some of your medical and nutritional insights into the program.I was thinking we could have a brainstorming session next week to discuss the content and structure of the workshops. I'd love to hear your thoughts on the latest research and how we can best support our clients in making lifestyle changes that promote better gut health.Let me know if you're interested and when you're available to meet.Best regards,Emily

body: i'll pay a grand total of 0"Eva Pao" <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu> on 05/10/2001 05:15:59 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu>   Please read the following problem very carefully, and write in a number atthe end.  You should be ready to defend your answer.  Only a number isallowed, not an algebraic equation.Acquiring a Company In the following exercise you will represent Company A (the acquirer),which is currently considering acquiring Company T (the target) by means ofa tender offer.  You plan to tender in cash for 100% of Company T's sharesbut are unsure how high a price to offer.  The main complication is this:the value of Company T depends directly on the outcome of a major oilexploration project it is currently undertaking.  Indeed, the very viabilityof Company T depends on the exploration outcome.  If the project fails, thecompany under current management will be worth nothing--$0/share.  But ifthe project succeeds, the value of the company under current managementcould be as high as $100/share.  All share values between $0 and $100 areconsidered equally likely.  By all estimates, the company will be worthconsiderably more in the hands of Company A than under current management.In fact, whatever the ultimate value under current management, the companywill be worth fifty percent more under the management of A than underCompany T.  If the project fails, the company is worth $0/share under eithermanagement.  If the exploration project generates a $50/share value undercurrent management, the value under Company A is $75/share.  Similarly, a$100/share value under Company T implies a $150/share value under Company A,and so on. The board of directors of Company A has asked you to determine the pricethey should offer for Company T's shares.  This offer must be made now,before the outcome of the drilling project is known.  From all indications,Company T would be happy to be acquired by Company A, provided it is at aprofitable price.  Moreover, Company T wishes to avoid, at all cost, thepotential of a takeover bid by any other firm.  You expect Company T todelay a decision on your bid until the results of the project are in, thenaccept or reject your offer before the news of the drilling results reachesthe press. Thus, you (Company A) will not know the results of the exploration projectwhen submitting your price offer, but Company T will know the results whendeciding whether or not to accept your offer.  In addition, Company T willaccept any offer by Company A that is greater than the (per share) value ofthe company under current management.  Thus, if you offer $50/share, forinstance, Company T will accept if the value of the company to Company T isanything less than $50. As the representative of Company A, you are deliberating over price offersin the range of $0/share (this is tantamount to making no offer at all) to$150/share.  What price offer per share would you tender for Company T'sstock? $______ per/share

body: Dear sir,     Hope this mail finds you well. I am Dhruv Gupta, an undergraduate student currently in my second year. I am writing this mail to you on behalf of my teammates regarding a project we need to do for the MA202 course.      The project revolves around the concepts of probability distribution and data analysis. We are required to find a mentor and do the project under his guidance. Therefore, I would like to meet you with my teammates to go through the various options for any such project in your area of expertise.Thanks and regards

body: <email>Hi David,It was wonderful to meet you at the War Studies Symposium last week. I really enjoyed our conversation about the economic motivations behind military interventions. Your perspective on the role of resource scarcity was particularly intriguing.I was thinking about your presentation on the way home and had some ideas for how we could potentially collaborate on a research project. I'd love to discuss this further with you if you're interested.Let me know if you'd like to set up a time to chat more.Best regards,Emily

body: <email>Emily,Thank you for reaching out. I'm excited to collaborate with you on this presentation. I agree that combining our research will provide a comprehensive understanding of the economic and social factors leading to the Civil War.Your suggestion to start by outlining the main differences between the North and the South is a great idea. We could then delve into the specific issues, such as the slave economy, industrialization, and westward expansion, and how these factors heightened tensions between the two regions.I think it would also be valuable to discuss the role of politics in exacerbating these divisions, such as the Missouri Compromise and the Kansas-Nebraska Act.If you're agreeable, I can start working on an outline for the presentation, focusing on the economic aspects, and you can tackle the social factors. We can then combine our work and refine it together.Let me know if you have any other ideas or suggestions. I'm looking forward to working with you on this project.Best,Michael
label: research

body: <email>Emily,Thank you for your email and for taking the lead on the presentation slides. I agree that incorporating personal anecdotes is a great way to make our research more relatable and engaging. I have a story about a camping trip I took with my family last summer that I think would be perfect for the presentation. I'll draft up a short version and send it your way for feedback.I also had an idea for a interactive activity we could do with the audience during the presentation. Since our research emphasizes the importance of spending time in nature, we could have attendees pair up and share their favorite outdoor activities or memories. This could help reinforce our message and create a more memorable experience for everyone.Let me know what you think about this idea, and if you have any other suggestions for making our presentation even more impactful. I'm looking forward to seeing our hard work come to fruition at the conference!Best,Michael
label: research

body: <email>Dear Alex,It's been an absolute pleasure working with you this year and watching your passion for chemistry grow. I'm thrilled to hear that you're considering pursuing this field further in college, and I have no doubt that you'll excel in your studies.I would be more than happy to write you a recommendation letter for your college applications. Please send me an email with the necessary information and deadlines, and I'll make sure to submit my letter in a timely manner.Thank you for your kind words, Alex. It means a great deal to me to know that I've made a positive impact on your educational journey. I'm looking forward to hearing about your future successes in chemistry.Best wishes,Emily Thompson

body: <email>Dear Emily,I'm thrilled to hear that you're enjoying the course and considering a career in software development! It's a rewarding field with many opportunities for growth and learning.If you're interested, I'd like to invite you to join a study group with some of the other students from the course. We meet online once a week to discuss the course material, work on coding exercises, and share our progress. It's a great way to collaborate and learn from each other.Please let me know if you'd like to join us. I'll be happy to provide you with the details.Keep up the great work, Emily! Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions or need further support.Best regards,John

body: <email>Hi Michael,I hope you're doing well! As you know, the community center is planning a special event to celebrate the upcoming solar eclipse. I think this is a fantastic opportunity for our history and science departments to collaborate and create something truly memorable for our community.I was wondering if you'd be interested in meeting to discuss ideas for incorporating historical elements into the event. I think it would be fascinating to explore how eclipses have been viewed and interpreted by different cultures throughout history, particularly in the context of Texas-Mexico relations.Please let me know if you have any initial thoughts or suggestions. I'm excited to work together on this!Best regards,Sarah

body: <email>Dear Alex,Thank you for reaching out. I am glad to hear that you are finding the concepts from our course applicable to your project on cache memory optimization. It is an interesting and challenging problem, and I would be happy to provide some guidance.In terms of mathematical modeling, I suggest you start by breaking down the problem into smaller, more manageable components. Consider the various factors that influence cache performance, such as cache size, block size, and replacement policies. You may find that techniques like Markov chains or queuing theory could be useful in modeling these aspects of the system.I would be happy to meet with you to discuss your project further. How about we schedule a meeting for next Tuesday at 3 pm in my office? Please let me know if this works for you.Best regards,Dr. Emily Davis

body: -----Original Message-----Sent:	Monday, July 23, 2001 1:03 PMCc:	Presto, Kevin M.; Tholan, Scott; Turner, NancySources at OPS indicate that once OPS completes its review of line 1110 and approves it to come back online, there is no formal process to grant El Paso permission to bring the entire system back to full capacity at 1.1 bcf/d. Therefore, once the inspection/repairs are completed by El Paso, the company will seek permission from OPS to resume to full service. OPS would probably grant them approval within a matter of days. The uncertainty still lies in the time it will take to interpret pigging data and for OPS to conduct its review.

Understanding the impact of the Pilgrim Fathers' journey on indigenous populations and systems of inequality is an important aspect of studying history.As for recommended readings, I suggest looking into "The Invasion of America" by Francis Jennings and "Mayflower" by Nathaniel Philbrick. body: <email>Amelia,That's fantastic news about the keynote invitation! I would be honored to join you as a co-presenter at the conference. It's a wonderful opportunity to showcase our work and engage with the broader academic community.I agree that the latest draft of our paper is in good shape, but I think we could still strengthen the conclusion by tying our findings more explicitly to the broader debates in the field. Perhaps we could highlight how our work contributes to the ongoing scholarly conversation about the role of religious institutions in shaping scientific discourse during this period.On a personal note, I wanted to thank you for all your support and encouragement throughout this project. Balancing research and family life can be challenging, but knowing that I have a colleague like you in my corner makes all the difference.Let me know when you're available to discuss our conference presentation in more detail. I'm excited to get started!Best,Ethan

body: ---------------------- 04:57 PM ---------------------------"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AMPlease respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com> "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> Enclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austinthat we told you about.  As you can tell from the proforma this projectshould produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.This is especially attractive when the project is in a market as strong asAustin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range forthis market.  This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that wehave uncovered to date in the Austin market.The project does have approved zoning and will only require a site plan.  Asit is in the "Smart Growth Corridor" area designated by the City of Austinfor preferred development, this will be fast tracked and should be completein less than 6 months.  Additionally, many of the current and more severewater treatment ordinances have been waived.  I have estimated the lotimprovement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in NorthAustin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and streetwidening.  Even though this property is not likely to require streetwidening and will have less of a detention/retention and filtration pondrequirement, I used this data to be cautious. The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is notexpected to impact sales significantly.  Other projects have been quitesuccessful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as theadjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.As with most infill projects, the quality of the surrounding neighborhoodsis uneven.  We have included a fence around the entire property, but mayonly put it on Westgate and Cameron Loop.  Gated communities are farpreferred so this is a good idea for both screening and current buyerpreferences.The seller accepted our offer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 andan extended escrow.  This will enable us to probably obtain an approved siteplan before closing on the contract, which will mean that we can close intoan A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.This analysis shows your investment at $700,000 for a 50% interest in theprofits of the project.  As we discussed in San Marcos, we can also discusshaving you invest only in the lots, sell the lots to the construction entitywith your profit in the lot.  I believe this would facilitate the use of a1031 Exchange of the proceeds from this deal into another project that is arental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would thenbe the equity for that project.  You would need to discuss this with anexchange expert first.  Larry Lewter knows an expert in the field in SanAntonio if you do not know anyone.I will send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,by Airborne Express today for Saturday delivery.Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want toschedule a tour of the site and the area.  Please get back to me as soon asyour schedule permits regarding the site visit and feel free to call at anytime.  You can reach me over the weekend and in the evening at either512-338-1119 or 512-338-1110.  My cell phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is512-338-1103.   I look forward to hearing from you and to working with youon this project that is sure to be a major winner.I regret that it took so long to get back to you, but we had some unusualevents these past few weeks.  A small freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpgdowndrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.One of these units had just had the roof decked with the siding scheduled tostart the next day.  The severe downdraft hitting the decked roof was enoughto knock it down.  The City shut down the project for a week and it tookanother week to get every thing back on tract.  Then last week I had to takemy wife  to emergency.  She has a bulge in the material between the vertebrain her spine and it causes her extreme pain and has kept her bedridden thispast week..  There is nothing like having your wife incapacitated to realizethe enormous number of things she does everyday.   Fortunately, it looks asif she will be ok in the long run.George W. RichardsCreekside Builders, LLC - Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls

body: <email>Hi Emily,It was great to meet you at the astronomy club meeting last night. I really enjoyed your presentation on the historical impact of celestial events on urban development. As someone who is passionate about space exploration and planetary science, I found your perspective fascinating.I was particularly intrigued by your insights on how advancements in space technology have influenced urban development throughout history. It's a topic I've been thinking about a lot lately, and I'd love to continue our conversation.If you're interested, I'd be happy to share some of the latest updates on the Cassini mission and the scientific discoveries that have come out of it. I think you might find it relevant to your work on historical disasters and urban transformation.Let me know if you'd like to chat more about this or if you have any other ideas for collaboration. I'm always excited to connect with people who share my interests.Best regards,Alex

body: <email>Hi Emily,I love the idea! I think it's a great way to get students to think about physics concepts in a new and creative way, and it's a perfect opportunity for them to expand their vocabulary at the same time. I'm definitely on board to collaborate with you on this project.I was thinking we could have the students work in small groups and give them a list of physics concepts and vocabulary words to choose from. That way, they can collaborate and bounce ideas off each other, and we can make sure that each group is working on a different concept and set of words.We could also have them present their stories or poems to the class and explain how they incorporated the physics concept and vocabulary words. That would give them a chance to practice their presentation skills and get feedback from their peers.Let me know what you think about these ideas, and we can start planning out the details of the project. I'm excited to work on this with you!Best,Michael

body: Jacques,The agreement looks fine.   My only comment is that George and Larry might object to the language that "the bank that was requested to finance the construction of the project declined to make the loan based on the high costs of the construction of the Project".   Technically, that bank lowered the loan amount based on lower estimates of rents which altered the amount of equity that would be required. Did I loan them $1,300,000?  I thought it was less.Regarding Exhibit A, the assets include:  the land, architectural plans, engineering completed, appraisal, and soils study.   Most of these items are in a state of partial completion by the consultants.  I have been speaking directly to the architect, engineer, and soils engineer.   I am unclear on what is the best way to proceed with these consultants.  The obligations should include the fees owed to the consultants above.  Do we need to list balances due or just list the work completed as an asset  and give consideration of $5,875 for the cash paid to the engineer and appraisor.Phillip

body: <email>Hi Emily,Thanks so much for reaching out! I'm excited to have connected with another teacher who is interested in integrating coding into math and science education. Your presentation on using spreadsheets to model exponential growth was really thought-provoking - I can definitely see how that could be adapted for use in my own classes.I'd be happy to share some of the materials I've been using to teach coding concepts in my science classes. I've attached a couple of lesson plans that use Scratch to simulate different ecological relationships, like predator-prey dynamics and food webs. I've found that starting with these concrete, real-world examples helps students understand why coding and computational thinking are useful skills to have.I'm also working on developing a series of activities that use Python to analyze and visualize data from our school's weather station. I'm still refining the curriculum, but I'm hoping to pilot it with my 8th graders next month. I'll keep you posted on how it goes!I'd love to take you up on your offer to visit your school sometime. I'm actually going to be in the Ridgemont area for a conference in a couple of months. Maybe we could arrange for me to come by and do a guest lesson or activity with your students while I'm there?Let me know what you think, and feel free to reach out anytime if you have any other questions or ideas to share.Best,Alex

body: <email>Dear Nusrat,I hope this email finds you well. I am reaching out to you because I am currently working on a book about the Telangana movement, and I have just completed a chapter that I believe would benefit greatly from your insights.The chapter focuses on the role of nationalism in the Telangana movement and draws parallels to other regional nationalist movements in South Asia. Given your expertise in the evolution and complexities of nationalism in Bangladesh, I would be incredibly grateful if you could take the time to review the chapter and provide your feedback.If you are willing to help, I can send you the chapter draft by the end of this week. Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.Best regards,Rajesh

body: <email>Dear Dr. Stewart,Thank you for reaching out. It's a pleasure to make your acquaintance, and I'm equally excited about our joint presentation. The topic is fascinating, and I believe our combined expertise will lead to a thought-provoking discussion.Sharing a room is a great idea. It will give us more opportunities to brainstorm and refine our presentation. Plus, it'll be nice to have some company in the evenings after the conference activities.I have a confession to make â€“ I'm a bit of a dinosaur enthusiast. As a child, I watched "Jurassic Park" countless times and dreamed of being a paleontologist. It's a pleasure to have the opportunity to work with someone who's made that dream a reality.I look forward to meeting you in Cusco and embarking on this intellectual adventure together.Best regards,Marcus

body: <email>Emily,I'm delighted to hear from you and am thrilled by your interest in incorporating classical literature into your electronics curriculum. I firmly believe that the themes and lessons from works like the Aeneid can be applied to various fields and can greatly benefit students' problem-solving and critical thinking skills.I would be more than happy to collaborate with you on this exciting venture. In fact, I have a few ideas in mind already! For instance, we could explore the theme of "innovation and tradition" by analyzing how Aeneas balances honoring tradition with embracing new ideas and technologies. This could tie in nicely with the concept of technological advancements in the electronics field.I'm available to meet next week on Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning. Please let me know which time works best for you, and we can further discuss our plans for this cross-disciplinary project.Looking forward to working together,Thomas

body: <email>Emily,Thank you for sharing the syllabus. I appreciate the thoroughness of your outline and the clear connections you've made between the scientific concepts and their real-world applications.As I was reviewing the syllabus, I had a few thoughts on how we could incorporate more social studies and civic engagement elements into the course. I'd like to see if we can find ways to encourage students to critically examine the societal implications of the scientific advancements we'll be discussing, and to consider their own roles and responsibilities as citizens in relation to these issues.For example, we could include case studies or discussion prompts that ask students to evaluate the ethical and social implications of certain scientific discoveries or technologies. We could also invite guest speakers from various fields (e.g., policy makers, activists, industry professionals) to share their perspectives and engage in dialogue with the students.I'm happy to discuss these ideas further and work with you to revise the syllabus accordingly. Please let me know your thoughts!Best,Michael

body: Traveling to have a business meeting takes the fun out of the trip.  Especially if you have to prepare a presentation.  I would suggest holding the business plan meetings here then take a trip without any formal business meetings.  I would even try and get some honest opinions on whether a trip is even desired or necessary.As far as the business meetings, I think it would be more productive to try and stimulate discussions across the different groups about what is working and what is not.  Too often the presenter speaks and the others are quiet just waiting for their turn.   The meetings might be better if held in a round table discussion format.  My suggestion for where to go is Austin.  Play golf and rent a ski boat and jet ski's.  Flying somewhere takes too much time.

body: <email>Dear Alice,Thank you for reaching out, and congratulations on your fascinating research topic! I am delighted to learn about your work on the influence of Chinese philosophy on Faulkner's writing, and I would be happy to share my insights on the twenty-four solar terms and their potential symbolic significance.Your focus on the "eternal return" and the cyclical nature of the seasons resonates with the core principles of the solar terms, which divide the year into 24 periods based on the sun's position and the lunar calendar. Each solar term represents a distinct phase in the seasonal cycle and is associated with specific agricultural and cultural practices.I would be particularly interested in discussing the ways in which Faulkner may have engaged with these ideas, either directly or indirectly, and how they might manifest in his use of seasonal imagery and themes. Perhaps we could explore the connection between the solar terms and the structure of some of his works, such as the cyclical narrative in "The Sound and the Fury."I am also intrigued by the possibility of co-authoring a paper or presenting at a conference together, as our research interests seem to complement each other nicely. Please let me know if you would like to discuss this further.I look forward to our continued exchange and the insights we may uncover together.Best regards,Liang Wei

I was hoping you might be able to help me create a study guide or some visual aids to make the information a bit easier to grasp. I know you're great at breaking down complex topics!In return, I'd be more than happy to help you out with anything you need for your U.S. history class. I remember how much I struggled with the 13 colonies when I was in high school, and I'd love to help you create some engaging activities for your students, especially any who might be struggling with the material.Let me know if you're up for a little sibling brainstroming session! I'm free this weekend if you are.Best,Emily

body: we need one more good shot of cool air to ensure complete and utter chaos for the next 10 months.  hopefully this is it.  you gotta love heffner...'if we take out the jan 31 low there is NO WAY anything bullish can happen'slafontaine@globalp.com on 02/08/2001 05:28:02 AM  thats what we wanna hear---------------------- 06:27 AM ---------------------------"Matt Rogers" <mrogers@earthsat.com> on 02/08/2001 03:46:47 AM    (b Steve LaFontaine/GlobalCo)Fax to:This morning's 6-10 day forecast models are showing somewhat betteragreement.  All three models move the main cold trough axis to the GreatLakes area by the last half of the period.  This shift allows for coldPolar/Arctic air to pour into the Midwest and Northeastern states bydays 9 and 10 (as early as day 8 on the American).  The Canadian andEuropean continue more troughing in the southern branch in theSouthwestern states, keeping that area cool, but also forcing continuedridging in the Southern states--from Texas to the Southeast--keepingthem warmer and away from the cold.  The American eliminates thissouthern branch cold air protection early (by day 8), while the Canadianbreaks it down by day 10, implying that even the South would see coldweather at the beginning of the 11-15 day period.  The European appearsto hold out the longest in bringing cold air to the South. In all cases,the West Coast should see some gradual warming by late in the period.All three models also continue a very amplified flow pattern in Canadawith a plentiful supply of strong, cold air.More details, including early information from the ensembles, will beavailable with the 6:30am ET release.-Matt Rogers

body: <email>Hi Ethan,I completely agree with your suggestions for the professional development sessions. Handouts on the key instructional strategies and sample lesson/unit plans will be incredibly helpful for teachers. And I love the idea of incorporating interactive elements like role-playing and practice sessions. I think that will really help the teachers feel more confident and prepared to implement the curriculum.You're welcome to take the lead on creating those training materials. I'll make sure the schools have the space and technology we need for those interactive components.I heard back from both Jefferson and Washington - they're both on board to participate in the pilot! I'll coordinate with them on meeting dates and will send you the details once they're set.Thanks again for all your partnership on this. I'm feeling really good about where we are and where we're headed!Best,Olivia

body: <email>Dear Amelia,Thank you for sending over the list of terms. I've taken a look and provided definitions and explanations for each one. I've attached the document for your review. Please let me know if you need any further clarification or have additional terms to add.Your suggestions for my upcoming lecture are incredibly helpful. I particularly like the idea of using analogies and visual aids to make the concepts more relatable. I'll definitely incorporate those strategies into my presentation. And I appreciate the advice on breaking up the lecture and encouraging audience engagement. I tend to get carried away with the details, so reminding myself to step back and check for understanding will be key.As for Ethan Chen, I do remember him! He was a few years ahead of me at Weston, but I recall him being a brilliant student with a real passion for physics. Small world that you know him as well.I'm attaching a draft of my lecture outline. I'd greatly appreciate any feedback you might have, particularly on the clarity and flow of the content. And please feel free to share the document with Ethan if you think he might have insights to offer.Thank you again for your help and collaboration on both the dictionary project and my lecture. I'm grateful for your expertise and support.Best regards,Julian Patel

body: <email>Dear Michael,I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to touch base with you about the upcoming paleontology conference where we've been invited to give a joint presentation. The organizers have asked us to submit a title and abstract for our talk by the end of the month.I was thinking we could focus our presentation on the evolutionary relationships between Permian and Triassic reptiles, highlighting some of our recent findings from our collaborative research. What do you think? Do you have any specific aspects of our work that you'd like to showcase?Also, we should start thinking about dividing up the work for the presentation. I'm happy to take the lead on creating the slides and outline, but I'd love your input on the content and any specific data or figures you'd like to include.Let me know your thoughts, and we can schedule a call to discuss further if needed.Best regards,Emily

body: Expected value of game = 1/2 * 0 + 1/4 * 1 + 1/8 *2 + 1/16 *4 +1/32 * 8+....       = 0       +.25  +.25 +.25 +.25  +...       = infinity"Eva Pao" <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu> on 05/13/2001 03:11:46 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba2002.hbs.edu>  -----Original Message-----Sent: Sunday, May 13, 2001 4:37 PMrules to a game:You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.  if you get heads, i give you$1.  Keep flipping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away withthe money.  however, each heads you get after the first you double yourmoney.  So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.  What'syou bid/offer on playing this game?  (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?what you charge me play against you?)

body: <email>Hi Michael,I love the idea of creating a companion website with additional resources! That will be a great way to supplement the video content and help students practice what they've learned. I can take on the task of creating the quizzes and practice problems.I also think it would be a good idea to create a section on the website where students can ask questions and we can respond to them. This will help us engage with our audience and provide additional support.As for the videos, I think we should aim to keep them around 10-15 minutes long, so that they're easy to digest. We can break down each topic into smaller subtopics and create separate videos for each one.What do you think about this plan? I'm really excited to get started on this project!Best regards,Emily

body: Catherine:Sorry it's been so long since I could respond.  With the craziness here I am way behind on everything.#1. 3 years#2.  volume way down on exchange recently with recent volatility.  volume probably averaging 25000 these days.  EOL volume averaging around 14000.   Very high percent of market.   Current market conditions shows why our transactional model of being one side of every trade is superior.  #3.  good liquidity first 3 years.  okay liquidity years 4-6.#4.  calendar 2004-2008 maybe 1 trade a day.  70% chance Enron is one side.  calendar 2009-2013  very rare that it trades.Catherine Pernot@ENRON12/01/2000 02:31 PM  Per my voicemail, I've included a list of the Investors' questions and preliminary answers.  The answers are attempts by our group, Bob Crane and Bryon Hoskins but need confirmation by you.  Would you mind giving us some feedback for #4 as well?  I could not find these numbers.  These are again going to be forwarded to Bain Capital, the potential equity investor in the pulp, paper and steel net works fund.  They are in their final stages of due diligence and are comparing pulp and paper facts with gas.  (They are under a confidentiality agreement).  Please call with any questionsThank you, Catherine Rentz Pernot X576541. # of years of NYMEX visibility on the typical gas curve.3 years2. # of daily trades on NYMEX, in total and for Enron specifically.102,492 daily trades on NYMEX (11/28/00)and ours amounts to 8,061 per day (usually around 10% daily NYMEX trades)3. length and nature of "price discovery" windows past the NYMEX portion ofthe gas curve (e.g., 7 years of visibility provided by proprietary marketmaking past NYMEX, then 10 years of macro / industry average assumptions).NYMEX price discovery equates to about 3 years. Liquidity of the market and proprietary market information equates to about 2 years after that with the remaining portion coming from more macro industry information.4. trade volume data (# of daily trades as well) for each 5 year increment ofthe gas curve beyond the NYMEX portion, in total and for Enron specifically. ??
