body: <email>Hi Michael,I hope you're doing well! I wanted to share with you my latest paper on a new statistical method for analyzing the spatial distribution of fossils in rock layers. I think you might find it interesting, given your work in geochronology and paleontology.The paper is titled "A novel approach to quantifying the spatial structure of fossil assemblages using multi-scale point pattern analysis" and was just published in the Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology. I've attached a copy for your reference.In the paper, I present a new method that combines geo-spatial analysis techniques with statistical tools to identify patterns in the distribution of fossils within rock layers. The method allows for a more detailed understanding of ancient ecosystems and can help us test hypotheses about the environmental factors that influenced the distribution of species in the past.I'd be really interested to hear your thoughts on the paper and whether you think this approach could be useful for your own research. Let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to discuss further!Best regards,Emily

body: <email>Hi Jordan,I hope this email finds you well. I was just reminiscing about our time at the conference and the great discussions we had about the intersection of our fields. I've made an incredible discovery that I think you'll be particularly interested in.While conducting a survey in a remote area, I stumbled upon what appears to be a previously unknown fish weir site. The structure is remarkably well-preserved, and I believe it could provide valuable insights into the ancient fishing practices and the surrounding ecosystem at the time of its construction.I immediately thought of you and your expertise in native plant species. I was hoping you could join me on this project and help me analyze the plant life in and around the site. Your input could be crucial in dating the weir and understanding its environmental context.I know you're busy, but I would be thrilled to have you on board. Please let me know if you're interested, and we can discuss the details further.Best regards,Alex

body: <email>Hey Olivia,I hope you're doing well! I've been thinking a lot about our conversations and your fascinating work in thermal medicine. I truly believe that my readers would be captivated by your research and the potential of this alternative treatment. I know you're hesitant about writing for a blog, but I have a proposal for you. What if we collaborated on a guest post? You could provide the technical details and findings, and I would help make it accessible and engaging for a general audience. It would be a great way to raise awareness about your work and the future of cancer treatment.Let me know what you think! If you're interested, I can send you some more information about my blog, audience, and the kind of content I usually produce. I'm excited about the possibility of working together and sharing your groundbreaking research with the world.Best regards,Ethan

body: In regards to gas:what signals do you for in determining your view?what resources do you use to formulate a price view?give example of complex transaction you've structured for a customer.where is storage now relative to history? what is the highest and lowest level we've been at in past 5 years?what are your short, medium, and long term views of gas market?what major basis changes have occured in the market over the past 5 years? What do you expect in the next 5?how should a storage operator decide whether or not to inject on any given day?In regards to derivatives in order of difficultyWhat are delta/gamma/theta?if you buy a put spread, is your delta positive, negative, or zero?Is swap price equal to simple average of futures contracts?If interest rates go up what happens to option prices all else equal?what is the value of a european $1 call expiring in 12 months if corresponding futures are trading $5?what happens to delta of an option if volatility increase?Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT  Jeanie Slone was telling me that you were among the best interviewers in the trading group.  Because of your expertise in this area, I was wondering if you could help me put some technical questions together that you've found to be effective in interviewing Gas Traders.Norma Hasenjager is in our Omaha office needs this information ASAP in order to help her screen some candidates.  It would be great if you could respond to this with two or three questions that you've used in the past to select good Gas Traders.Thanks for your help.Tom WilbeckEWS Training and Development

body: <email>Hi Alex,Thank you for your email and the course outline you shared. I really like your idea of including interactive 3D models of fossils â€“ it will definitely enhance the learning experience. However, I think we should also include some additional content on the geological context of these fossils and how they fit into the larger picture of Earth's history.I've made some suggestions and edits to the outline, which I've attached to this email. Please feel free to review and provide your thoughts. I'm open to further discussion and refinement.Regarding our call, Wednesday morning works great for me. Please send over the calendar invite whenever convenient.I'm excited to see how this course takes shape and am looking forward to our collaboration!Best,Emily
label: research

body: <email>Hi John,You're absolutely right about the impact our curriculum could have. I'm thrilled to be working with you on this project.Regarding the primary sources, I have a few in mind that I think would work well. I'll compile them and send them your way for review. If you have any suggestions for additional sources, please let me know.I'll also start working on the overview for the handouts and will send you a draft early next week. Please feel free to make any changes or additions as you see fit.I'm looking forward to our presentation at the conference. I have no doubt it will be a success!Best,Emily

body: <email>Dear Samuel,Thank you for reaching out, and I'm glad to hear that our discussions at the conference left a lasting impression. Your research on the new species of Salticidae jumping spider with unique mimicry abilities sounds truly remarkable, and I would be very interested in learning more about your findings.The potential link between modern spider behavior and their ancient ancestors is a fascinating area of research, and I believe that our combined expertise could indeed lead to some groundbreaking discoveries. The newly discovered fossil site in Mongolia is an extraordinary opportunity to gather valuable data and specimens that could shed light on the evolutionary history of spider mimicry and communication.I would be delighted to discuss the possibility of a collaboration and the joint grant application in more detail. Perhaps we could set up a video call next week to share our latest research findings and explore the potential for a joint project?Looking forward to hearing back from you soon.Best regards,Evelyn Blackwell, PhDAssociate Professor of PalaeoarachnologyPaleospiders Institute

body: <email>Dear Ms. Johnson,Thank you for reaching out, and I'm delighted to hear about your curriculum project. As someone who is passionate about Acadian history and its role in shaping the unique culture of Louisiana, I would be more than happy to assist you in any way I can.I think it's wonderful that you're incorporating primary sources and historical documents into your lessons. Some excellent resources to consider include:1. The "Memorial of the French Inhabitants of Louisiana to the King of France" (1755)2. The "Treaty of Paris" (1763)3. First-hand accounts from Acadian deportees during the Grand DÃ©rangement (1755-1764)4. Newspaper articles from the time period discussing the Acadians' plightIn terms of engaging lesson ideas, I've found that role-playing activities, where students take on the perspectives of different historical figures, can be incredibly effective in helping them understand the complexities of the time period.I'm also happy to provide some broader historical context and analysis to help frame the materials you incorporate into your lessons.Please feel free to reach out with any other questions or requests. I look forward to working with you on this important project.Best regards,David Theriot
label: research

body: [IMAGE]	Fantasy Football Newsletter	  November 23, 2001  			     [IMAGE]Fantasy Sports     [IMAGE]Fantasy Football     [IMAGE]CBS SportsLine.com 		  Welcome to another edition of the 2001 Fantasy Football Newsletter!      The Fantasy Football newsletter will arrive in your e-mail inbox every Friday. We'll include news about the web site; tips on using all the features available; and answers to your player-related questions from the "Gridiron Guru."   	[IMAGE]	Inside      ? Thanksgiving Football   ? Sortable Standings   ? Gridiron Guru   ? Tip of the Week   	 [IMAGE]  [IMAGE]  [IMAGE]  	    Thanksgiving Football     Remember that two NFL games will be played on Thursday: Packers vs. Lions at 12:30 PM ET and Broncos vs. Cowboys at 4:05 PM ET. Fantasy 2001 players, if you have players from these four teams on your roster, they must have their final status (active or reserve) set 5 minutes before the start of their game. Please keep in mind that you also will not be able to enter any new add/drops for the week starting one hour prior to Thursday's first kickoff. Football Commissioner players, check with your league's commissioner to see how your lineup deadline is handled this week.  	    Sortable Standings     Did you know that every column on your Standings page is sortable? Click the category name at the top of any column to sort the report by the results of that category. In head- to-head leagues, the Standings report is displayed in order of the teams with the best win/loss percentage. However, you can click the PF (Points For) column to display the top point-scoring teams at the top; or the PA (Points Against) column to display, in descending order, the teams with the most fantasy points scored against them.  	    Gridiron Guru     Welcome to Gridiron Guru, where we'll answer your questions about players and offer Fantasy Football roster advice. We invite you to send your own scouting reports and comments on players to: gridguru@commissioner.com . You'll get the chance to be heard by thousands of Fantasy players just like yourself!   	  Question - Marcus Howell     Who would you start in Week 11: Brian Griese  at Dallas or Jake Plummer at San Diego?    Answer - GG     Griese's receiving corps has been crippled by injuries  this season, and with Rod Smith questionable with an ankle  injury, the outlook gets dimmer. The Denver QB has been  bothered by physical problems this year as well. Plummer  seems like a better choice after a superb Week 10 outing. But  remember that he was facing the 0-9 Lions, and Plummer has  never been able to string many good performances together in  the past. He will be facing a San Diego defense that will be  primed for a good performance after getting burned badly by  Oakland last week. Go with Griese, who should at least post  respectable numbers at Dallas.  	  Question - Eric Fernau     Which three running backs should I start?  I  have Corey Dillon, Ricky Williams, Duce Staley, Priest  Holmes and Garrison Hearst.    Answer - GG     Dillon is a must-start player every week. Holmes is  facing a Seattle defense that looks good statistically, but  will have a lot of trouble containing him on the outside.  Staley should have little trouble ripping through the  Washington front wall. It's hard to ignore Hearst at  Indianapolis or Williams in any week, but we like Dillon,  Holmes and Staley, especially the latter in an NFC East game.  	  Question - Jay Rassat     Who do I start this week at quarterback? I have  Tom Brady, Aaron Brooks and Trent Green. The defenses they  play against are all decent (N.O., N.E. and Seattle).    Answer - GG     Brady and Brooks square off against each other, and  each is facing a secondary that can give up the big play.  Green will be facing a Seattle team that won't offer much of  a pass rush, but he is less explosive than Brooks or Brady.  With Brady having the advantage of playing at home, and Drew  Bledsoe looking over his shoulder, we'll go with the New  England QB.  	    Tip of the Week      Ryan Carter, Watertown, CT: Ricky Watters' decision to not  have shoulder surgery is bad news for him, but great news for  people like me, who have Shaun Alexander. I would not be  surprised to see Watters not play again this year. Ricky's a  great back, and I wish him well, but you cannot replace a  back like Alexander.  	  This message has been provided free of charge and free of obligation. If you prefer not to receive emails of this nature please send an email to remove@commissioner.com . Do not respond to this email directly.
label: research

body: <email>David,I hope you're doing well! I wanted to share some incredible news with you. While digging through the archives at the University of Puerto Rico, I stumbled upon a collection of letters between Puerto Rican independence activists from the late 19th century. The letters discuss the role of genetics in shaping the island's identity and resisting colonial oppression.I immediately thought of our research project and how these letters could provide valuable context for our work. I've attached a few scanned copies of the most relevant letters for you to take a look at.What do you think about incorporating these letters into our study? I believe they could offer a unique perspective on the intersection of history, genetics, and social justice in Puerto Rico.Let me know your thoughts!Best regards,Maria
label: research

body: Phillip,Here are the key points that came out of today's meeting:1. We will move Conversion and Arbitrage from the Simulation layer into theKnowledge System layer. We will incorporate 5-10 problems of each type.2. You will provide us with the name(s) of people who can give us contentfor these problems. We will set up two rounds of meetings; one early nextweek to gather content and a second meeting for review.3. We will change "Gas Daily Risk" to "Intra-Month Risk" throughout thesimulation. Can you provide us with a definition of Intra-Month risk?4. Just to clarify: For conversion, we were planning to cover problemswhere there is no perfect hedge so the learner has to find creative ways tohedge, as opposed to conversion of mmBTU to decatherms, conversion of oilvolumes to natural gas volumes, etc. Is that what you had in mind too?Thank you in advance for your help. Have a great Thanksgiving.MeryThis message is for the designated recipient only and may containprivileged, proprietary, or otherwise private information.  If you havereceived it in error, please notify the sender immediately and delete theoriginal.  Any other use of the email by you is prohibited.

body: <email>Hi Alex,Thank you for your ongoing support and encouragement. It means so much to me to have a trusted colleague and mentor like you to turn to as I navigate this new role.I love your idea of co-authoring an article or presenting at a conference together! That could be a fantastic way to share our insights and experiences with a broader audience and to amplify our impact. I would be thrilled to collaborate with you on a project like that. Let's touch base soon to brainstorm some specific ideas and to identify potential outlets or events where we could share our work.In the meantime, I will keep you posted on my progress and will definitely reach out with any questions or updates. I'm so grateful for your partnership and for the opportunity to work together to create more inclusive and equitable schools.Thank you again for everything!Warmly,Jenna

body: sureGriffith/Corp/Enron@Enron, Dutch Quigley/HOU/ECT@ECT  John,Thank you for your flexibility regarding the asian option we purchased from you (average Feb-Aug GD HH settle).  Unfortunately, our customer would like to settle on 7 days, using the preceding day for any day for which Gas Daily is not published (i.e., Friday prices would be used for Saturday and Sunday) - so I know it's not your preference, but I need to take advantage of your offer.Regards,Garyx31511John Arnold10/08/2000 02:05 PM  I can do it either way but would much rather just make it the simple average of prices, 5 per week.   				  John(s),How will the Asian options we purchased from the gas desk settle with respect to weekends... will the average of every day's gas daily settle mean the average of only the days on which Gas Daily is published?  or will it triple count each Friday's or Monday's price to account for the weekend (with a similar calculation on weekends).  I assume it is the former, not the latter.  Is this correct?  Are you indifferent if we want to switch to the latter?  Intuitively, it would seem to me that at this point, it wouldn't matter (because Friday or Monday prices are just as likely to be above the average as below the average), but you're wearing the risk, not us - so let me know.Frankly, we don't have a preference as a desk, except that we need the settlement to be consistent with the deal we are entering into with SMUD.  SMUD has questioned our calculation and I need to know how much I need to argue for one or the other.Regards,Garyx31511

body: The EOL Reporting Database treats any distinct deal number as a separate unique deal.  An example would be a deal done with KUKUI Inc. on November 8th, 2000.  It is booked as deal numbers Q86409.1, Q86409.2, Q86409.3, and Q86409.4.  These are four separate and unique deal numbers and therefore count as a total of four deals.     We understand that the trade desk may consider the deal in this example as just one large deal with 4 different parts.  Unfortunately,  the EOL Reporting Database has no way of telling whether or not these types of deals are distinct different deals or part of one larger deal.  Since this currently can not be known, the EOL Reporting Database uses the most conservative approach and counts them all as individual deals.  This results in a higher OTC deal count and thus a lower EOL percentage of all deals.If you have any further questions , please don't hesitate to ask.Pete Berzinsx57597

body: <email>Hi Daniel,I'm so glad you like the revisions! I'll incorporate your suggestions for additional examples this weekend. Dinner on the 15th sounds great - I'll do some research on the best restaurants in the area and send you my top picks.I completely agree with you about the potential impact of our research. It's been such a rewarding collaboration, and I'm excited to see where it takes us next. Speaking of which, have you given any more thought to the idea of publishing our work in an academic journal? I think it could really help us reach a wider audience and get more feedback from our peers.Let me know what you think, and I'll start looking into potential journals that might be a good fit for our paper.See you soon in Chicago!Best,Emily

body: <email>Liam,I'm glad you're as enthusiastic about this collaboration as I am! I love your idea of creating a series of stories with accompanying activities and resources. We could also consider ways to make the stories interactive and adaptable to different cultural contexts.I'm available for a call next week on Tuesday, April 12th at 10 am my time (GMT+1). Let me know if that works for you, and feel free to suggest an alternative time if needed.I'm looking forward to our discussion and the potential impact our project could have on child health and education!Best,Sophia

body: <email>Jordan,Thank you so much for accommodating my visit on such short notice. I'm thrilled that we'll have the opportunity to discuss our research in person.If possible, I'd love to learn more about the chemical analysis techniques you use for dating and understanding the composition of archaeological materials. I think this could be particularly relevant to my work on prehistoric fish weirs and the materials used in their construction.I'm also interested in any insights you might have on how the mole concept could be applied to archaeological chemistry. I've been reading up on it since our last conversation, and I think there could be some exciting possibilities for our collaboration.Please let me know if there's anything I can do to prepare for our meeting. I'm eager to learn from you and your team.Best,Alex
label: research

If you get tails you win 0.  if you get heads, i give you$1.  Keep flipping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away withthe money.  however, each heads you get after the first you double yourmoney.  So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.  What'syou bid/offer on playing this game?  (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?what you charge me play against you?)

body: <email>Dear Amelia,Next Friday, April 16th, at 10 AM AEST works perfectly for me. I'll send you a calendar invite with the video conference details. I've also reached out to my contacts at the Australian Research Council and have a meeting scheduled with them next week to discuss our project.I'm glad to hear that your daughter, Sophia, is also interested in science. Finn would be thrilled to meet her. Let's plan a weekend get-together once we have made some progress on our project. Perhaps we could visit a local science museum or organize a picnic in a park where the kids can explore nature together.I'm equally excited about the potential impact our collaboration could have on public health and agriculture. With our combined expertise, I believe we can make significant strides in this innovative research.Looking forward to our video conference next week.Best regards,Liam

body: <email>Dear Dr. Patel,I hope this email finds you well. I recently came across some disturbing news about a new strain of the Zika virus that has been identified in our region. As you know, we've been working together to address vector-borne diseases for years now, and I believe this development warrants our immediate attention.Given your expertise in infectious diseases and your connections in Singapore, I was wondering if you might have any insights or recommendations on how we can tackle this emerging threat. I'm particularly interested in learning more about the vector control program you mentioned during our last webinar, as I believe it could be a valuable model for us to consider here in Miami.Would you be available for a call next week to discuss this further? I'd love to brainstorm some ideas and explore potential collaborative efforts to address this outbreak.Best regards,Emily JohnsonVector-Borne Disease Prevention and ControlCity of Miami

body: <email>Alex,Thanks for the update! I'm thrilled to hear about the new fossil data and can't wait to dive into your analysis. I'll review everything this weekend and send you my feedback early next week.I'm also excited about the hiking plans you've been working on. It's going to be incredible to see these sites in person and imagine what life was like for both the reptiles and humans who inhabited the region millions of years ago.On a separate note, I came across an interesting article about the use of reptile bones as tools by early humans in the American Southwest. I'll forward it to you, as I think it could provide some valuable context for our research.I'm looking forward to our call next week and discussing our next steps for the project. Let me know if there's anything else I can do to help in the meantime.Best,Jordan

body: <email>Hi Alex,It's great to hear from you! I'm thrilled that you're taking the lead on planning our hiking trip this year. Both the Rocky Mountains and the Pacific Northwest sound amazing, but I think I'd lean towards the coastal hike. There's just something magical about the ocean breeze and the rugged coastline that I find incredibly refreshing.As for your gastroenterologist appointment, try not to worry too much. The doctor will likely start with a thorough medical history and physical exam, and then discuss any necessary tests or procedures. Remember, they're there to help you, so don't hesitate to ask questions or voice any concerns you may have. If you'd like, I can recommend a fantastic gastroenterologist in your area who I think you'd really like.On another note, I've been giving a lot of thought to that job offer I mentioned. It's a fantastic opportunity, but the thought of leaving my current practice and moving away from friends and family is really weighing on me. I know I can always count on your objective perspective, so I'd love to chat more about this when we have a chance.Let me know what you think about the coastal hike, and we can start making more concrete plans. I'm excited to get out on the trails with you again!Best,Emily

body: <email>Michael,Thanks for your prompt response. I've just finished analyzing the network traffic logs from one of the affected clients, and I found something disturbing. The malware seems to have been delivered through a spear-phishing email that originated from within the client's own network. This suggests that the attackers may have had help from an insider.I've attached the relevant logs for your review. Can you take a look and let me know your thoughts?Also, I'll join the call at 2 PM. In the meantime, I'll continue working on identifying the extent of the damage and gathering more evidence.Best,Samantha

body: <email>Hi Michael,I hope you're doing well. I wanted to thank you again for your fantastic collaboration during the professional development workshop. The feedback we received from our colleagues was overwhelmingly positive, and I believe our presentation made a significant impact.Several teachers approached us after the workshop, expressing their interest in implementing some of our strategies in their classrooms. I think this is a testament to the effectiveness of our collaborative approach.I'd love to continue working with you on more projects and share our knowledge with other teachers in the school. Perhaps we can organize a series of workshops or create a resource bank for our colleagues to access.Let me know your thoughts, and let's schedule a meeting to discuss our next steps.Best regards,Sarah

body: Thanks.Andy Zipper@ENRON07/19/2000 08:27 AM  By the version of EOL do you mean the new version of stack manager ? If you do, we should have finished testing by today. That means we will roll out today or tomorrow, but Louise wants a more developed roll out plan, so that might slow things down a bit. Not to make excuses, but we have had some serious technical problems with the new release and have had to redesign whole parts of the back end of the system. The problem is around how many things can be linked to a single product and stack manager performance, obviously a serious issue. It has taken us, obviously, a lot longer than we thought to fix it. I think there are still some minor issues that we should discuss, but they should not get in the way of release.If you mean by new version, the phase II website version with sexy content, we are scheduled (cum grano salis) to roll that out in mid august.any questions please feel free to call.-andy
label: corporate

body: <email>Alex,Thank you for your prompt response. I'm glad to hear you're as intrigued by this mystery as I am. I would be more than happy to discuss my experience in Pineville and any potential environmental factors I noticed during my trip.Next week works well for me to set up a call and plan our research trip to Willow Creek. I'm available on Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning, if either of those times work for you. I'll also start gathering any relevant data and resources we might need for our field research.I'm looking forward to working together on this project and uncovering the truth behind these mysterious occurrences.Best regards,Emily
label: research

body: <email>Hi Emily,Great to hear that you're as excited about this finding as I am! I'm glad you agree that it could be a significant discovery. I think collaborating with our colleagues at the institute is an excellent idea. Their expertise in planetary geology and volcanism will be invaluable in interpreting this data.I'm available next Monday and Wednesday afternoons if that works for you. We could meet in the lab and go over the data together. Let me know what time suits you best.Your section on Europa's subsurface ocean sounds fascinating! I think it will be a great addition to our presentation. I agree that highlighting the interdisciplinary nature of our research will showcase the strength of our collaboration.I'll send you the latest draft of my section by the end of this week for your feedback. I'm happy to make any adjustments based on your suggestions.Looking forward to our meeting next week!Best,Jordan
label: research

body: Ned,Regarding the Waha storage, the west desk does not have a strong need for this storage but we are always willing to show a bid based on the current summer/winter spreads and cycling value.  The following assumptions were made to establish our bid:  5% daily injection capacity, 10% daily withdrawal capacity, 1% fuel (injection only), 0.01/MMBtu variable injection and withdrawal fees.  Also an undiscounted  June 01 to January 02 spread of $0.60 existed at the time of this bid.Bid for a 1 year storage contract beginning June 01 based on above assumptions:  $0.05/ MMBtu/Month ($0.60/Year).  Demand charges only.I am not sure if this is exactly what you need or not.  Please call or email with comments.Phillip Allen
label: corporate

body: ---------------------- 08:45 AM ---------------------------   				  I want to pass on my sincere appreciation for the excellent work and assistance from Colleen Koenig during last weeks crisis management program in Venezuela.  Colleen was more than helpful and provided services that I found invaluable.  She was extremely well liked by the senior management of Vengas and spent a great deal of time with them in creating an environment conducive to teamwork and productivity.  Her language skills, knowledge and personality provided an incredible resource.  Thanks for allowing my program her services and I look forward to working with her again in the future.Jim Rountree
label: corporate

body: Russell:My risk group frequently uses the New Counterparty label for internal counterparties that do not have a trading book.  This transaction was a hedge for the acquisition of the paper plant we announced recently.  I'm not sure who the internal group is that did the transaction.  Dutch Quigley should be able to help.John.        07/19/2000 05:22 PM				                           	  JohnA trade came across our morning report listed as a 'New Counterparty'.  It was about 17BCF Swap from Sep "00  - Aug '07.  Can you give me some details on the counterparty.Thank you,RussellCredit
label: corporate

body: <email>Hi Alex,It was great meeting you at the Solar Physics Conference last week! I really enjoyed our discussion about the historical advancements in solar research methodologies. I'm writing to share the article I mentioned about the application of machine learning techniques in analyzing solar data. I thought you might find it interesting given your research focus.Let me know if you'd like to chat more about this topic or if you come across any other relevant articles. I'm always eager to learn from others in the field.Best regards,Emily
label: research

body: Good job....I've got 10% of my portfolio in CGP.   Keep up the good work."Cooper, Sean" <CooperS@EPEnergy.com> on 07/11/2000 08:03:41 PM  Per Sharehttp://biz.yahoo.com/prnews/000711/tx_el_paso_2.htmlTuesday July 11, 5:42 pm Eastern TimeCompany Press ReleaseSOURCE: El Paso Energy CorporationEl Paso Energy Corporation Reports Record Second Quarter Earnings Per ShareHOUSTON, July 11 /PRNewswire/ -- El Paso Energy Corporation (NYSE: EPG<http://finance.yahoo.com/q?s=epg&d=t> - news </n/e/epg.html>) todayannounced second quarter 2000 adjusted diluted earnings per share of $0.69,an increase of 73 percent over second quarter 1999 adjusted diluted earningsper share of $0.40. The second quarter 2000 results exclude $0.13 per shareof one-time merger-related items. Diluted average common shares outstandingfor the second quarter 2000 totaled 242 million. Consolidated adjustedearnings before interest expense and income taxes (EBIT) for the secondquarter increased by 55 percent to $408 million, compared with $263 millionin the year-ago period.EBIT from the company's non-regulated businesses more than tripled in thequarter to $246 million, and represented 60 percent of consolidated EBIT.``Outstanding growth in Merchant Energy and continued strong performance inour other non-regulated segments produced these record results,'' saidWilliam A. Wise, president and chief executive officer of El Paso EnergyCorporation. ``Reflecting our long-standing strategy of building a portfolioof flexible gas and power assets, Merchant Energy's earnings continued toaccelerate in the second quarter.''For the first six months of 2000, adjusted diluted earnings per shareincreased 84 percent to $1.40 per share, compared with $0.76 for the firstsix months of 1999. Consolidated EBIT for the six months, excludingnon-recurring items, increased 55 percent to $798 million compared with $515million in the year-ago period.Second Quarter Business Segment ResultsThe Merchant Energy segment reported record EBIT of $152 million in thesecond quarter 2000, compared with $6 million in the same period last yearand $50 million in the first quarter 2000. The physical and financial gasand power portfolio developed over the past several years is creatingsignificant value in the current volatile energy environment. Enhancedtrading opportunities around our asset positions, continued strong wholesalecustomer business, and management fees from Project Electron (the company'soff-balance sheet vehicle for power generation investments) all contributedto the record second-quarter performance.The Production segment reported a 30-percent increase in second quarter EBITto $52 million compared with $40 million a year ago, reflecting higherrealized gas and oil prices and lower operating costs following thereorganization of its business in 1999. Weighted average realized prices forthe quarter were $2.26 per million cubic feet (MMcf) of natural gas and$19.21 per barrel of oil, up 12 percent and 29 percent, respectively, fromthe year-ago levels. Average natural gas production totaled 512 MMcf per dayand oil production averaged 14,275 barrels per day.The Field Services segment reported second quarter EBIT of $30 million,nearly double an adjusted $16 million in 1999. The increase was dueprimarily to higher realized gathering and processing margins, together withthe acquisition of an interest in the Indian Basin processing plant in March2000. Second quarter gathering and treating volumes averaged 4.1 trillionBtu per day (TBtu/d), while processing volumes averaged 1.1 TBtu/d.Coming out of one of the warmest winters on record, the Natural GasTransmission segment reported second quarter EBIT of $190 million comparedwith an adjusted $187 million a year ago, reflecting the realization of costsavings from the Sonat merger. Overall system throughput averaged 11.3TBtu/d. During the quarter, Southern Natural Gas received Federal EnergyRegulatory Commission approval of its comprehensive rate case settlementfiled in March.The International segment reported second quarter EBIT of $12 millioncompared with $16 million in 1999. Higher equity income from projects inBrazil and Argentina largely offset lower equity earnings from the company'sinvestment in the Philippines.Telecom Update``We have made substantial progress in the development of ourtelecommunications business, El Paso Global Networks,'' said William A.Wise. ``Reflecting our market-centric approach to developing new businesses,we have named Greg G. Jenkins, the current president of El Paso MerchantEnergy, to head our telecommunications business. Our expertise in buildingbusinesses in rapidly commoditizing markets, as demonstrated by our MerchantEnergy success, provides us with a key competitive entry point in thetelecommunications marketplace.''Quarterly DividendThe Board of Directors declared a quarterly dividend of $0.206 per share onthe company's outstanding common stock. The dividend will be payable October2, 2000 to shareholders of record as of the close of business on September1, 2000. There were 237,786,853 outstanding shares of common stock entitledto receive dividends as of June 30, 2000.With over $19 billion in assets, El Paso Energy Corporation providescomprehensive energy solutions through its strategic business units:Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company, El Paso Natural Gas Company, SouthernNatural Gas Company, El Paso Merchant Energy Company, El Paso EnergyInternational Company, El Paso Field Services Company, and El PasoProduction Company. The company owns North America's largest natural gaspipeline system, both in terms of throughput and miles of pipeline, and hasoperations in natural gas transmission, merchant energy services, powergeneration, international project development, gas gathering and processing,and gas and oil production. On May 5, the stockholders of both El PasoEnergy and The Coastal Corporation overwhelmingly voted in favor of mergingthe two organizations. The combined company will have assets of $35 billionand be one of the world's leading integrated energy companies. The merger isexpected to close in the fourth quarter of this year, concurrent with thecompletion of regulatory reviews. Visit El Paso Energy's web site atwww.epenergy.com <http://www.epenergy.com>.Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking StatementsThis release includes forward-looking statements and projections, made inreliance on the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities LitigationReform Act of 1995. The company has made every reasonable effort to ensurethat the information and assumptions on which these statements andprojections are based are current, reasonable, and complete. However, avariety of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from theprojections, anticipated results or other expectations expressed in thisrelease. While the company makes these statements and projections in goodfaith, neither the company nor its management can guarantee that theanticipated future results will be achieved. Reference should be made to thecompany's (and its affiliates') Securities and Exchange Commission filingsfor additional important factors that may affect actual results. body: George, Below is a list of questions that Keith and I had regarding the Westgate project: Ownership Structure What will be the ownership structure? Limited partnership? General partner? What are all the legal entities that will be involved and in what capacity(regarding ownership and  liabilities)? Who owns the land? improvements? Who holds the various loans? Is the land collateral? Investment  What happens to initial investment? Is it used to purchase land for cash?Secure future loans?  Why is the land cost spread out on the cash flow statement? When is the 700,000 actually needed? Now or for the land closing? Investment schedule? Investment Return Is Equity Repayment the return of the original investment? Is the plan to wait until the last unit is sold and closed before profits are distributed? Debt Which entity is the borrower for each loan and what recourse or collateral is associated with each  loan? Improvement Construction Are these the only two loans?  Looks like it from the cash flow statement. Terms of each loan? Uses of Funds How will disbursements be made?  By whom? What type of bank account?  Controls on max disbursement? Internet viewing for investors? Reports to track expenses vs plan? Bookkeeping procedures to record actual expenses? What is the relationship of Creekside Builders to the project?  Do you get paid a markup on subcontractors as a  general contractor and paid gain out of profits? Do you or Larry receive any money in the form of salary or personal expenses before the ultimate payout of profits? Design and Construction  When will design be complete? What input will investors have in selecting design and materials for units? What level of investor involvement will be possible during construction planning and permitting? Does Creekside have specific procedures for dealing with subcontractors, vendors, and other professionals?  Such as always getting 3 bids, payment schedules, or reference checking? Are there any specific companies or individuals that you already plan to use? Names?These questions are probably very basic to you, but as a first time investor in a project like this it is new to me.  Also, I want to learn asmuch as possible from the process.Phillip

body: Re: trucking LNG to California - The short answer is that trucking LNG to California is not a feasible option for endusers other than companies with LNG-fueled vehicle fleets. There are a couple of reasons for this. First, California has a relative abundance of LNG fueling stations but only two plants capable of regasification. One serves Borrego Springs, a small, affluent desert community near San Diego. The other is dedicated to military and industrial supply near Sacramento. I spoke this morning to Applied LNG Technologies, which is based in Amarillo and has the second largest LNG truck fleet (after Transgas in Massachusetts). It shouldn't be a surprise that I was not the first to call regarding this question. While ALT's fleet is operating at capacity - trucking LNG from liquefaction plants in Wyoming and Topock, Arizona - it's serving its normal fleet customers in Southern California and Nevada, and Arizona. The Topock, AZ plant is owned jointly by ALT and El Paso, and receives gas from El Paso for liquefaction and subsequent loading onto trucks.Second, LNG trucks, unlike LNG tankers, carry an extremely small volume. The average truck carries 10,000 gallons of LNG, which translates roughly into 820,000 cubic feet. ALT has about 23 vehicles so potentially one could deliver 18.8 mmcf. However, these trucks don't regasify LNG, they merely transfer it into storage. The only really viable option for putting gas into the pipeline system would be a portable pipeline unit, of which ALT has the only one (it's under repair). It can deliver high pressure gas at 1800 cubic feet/minute (2.6 mmcf/day if it runs 24 hours). It has connections for two LNG trucks at a time - one live and one backup, so it can operate continuously. In the past, ALT has used the unit to cover industrials who had a supply outage for some reason. I'm going to continue gathering info on domestic LNG peakshaving plants, etc. I think the opportunity may lie more in future, more strategically located peakshaving plants rather than LNG trucking arbitrage. Please let me know if you have specific questions.

body: <email>Hey Michael,I hope you're having a great week so far! I wanted to run a new project idea by you that I think could be really engaging for our students. I was thinking about how we could combine vocabulary development with physics concepts, and I came up with an idea for a project called "The Physics of Language."The basic premise is that students would choose a physics concept (like gravity, friction, or momentum) and then write a short story or poem that incorporates vocabulary words related to that concept. The story or poem would need to demonstrate an understanding of the physics concept and use the vocabulary words in a meaningful way.I think this project could help our students see the connections between language and science, and it would give them a chance to be creative while also learning important concepts in both subjects. What do you think? Would you be interested in collaborating on this project with me?Let me know your thoughts!Best,Emily

body: Enron employees not participating in contract parking are eligible to receive Metro Bus Passes or Woodlands Express Passes.  You may pick up a bus pass from the Parking & Transportation Desk, on Level 3 of the Enron Building, from 8:30 AM to 4:30 PM. All Metro passes offered through the Enron Parking & Transportation desk will be the Metro 30 Day Zone Pass.  When you use a 30-day zone pass, bus service is divided into four zones w/ unlimited rides.  The zone pass is time activated, which means that it will not become active until the first time it is used and will not expire until 30 days after it was used for the first time.  New passes will be available to Enron employees upon expiration of the 30 day time period. Each zone does have a different fare values based on the distance the bus travels. This is important to any buser who wants to transfer to or travel in a higher-cost zone than the zone pass they have, in this case the difference must be paid in cash.  If they are traveling in a lower cost zone, then there is no extra cost.  Parking & Transportation Desk3-7060

body: <email>Dear Emily,It's wonderful to hear from you! I remember our meeting at the conference and am thrilled to hear that my talk had a lasting impact on you. I would be more than happy to assist you in developing your lesson plan on the intersection of women's rights and politics in the 20th century.Some key figures and events that I believe are essential to include are:1. The women's suffrage movement and the passage of the 19th Amendment in 19202. The role of women in the workforce during World War II and the subsequent push for equal pay3. The Civil Rights Movement and the intersection of gender and race in the struggle for equality4. The women's liberation movement of the 1960s and 70s, including the fight for reproductive rights and the Equal Rights Amendment5. The impact of Title IX on women's education and athleticsAs for resources, I highly recommend the following books:- "The Woman Suffrage Movement in America" by Corrine M. McConnaughy- "The Feminine Mystique" by Betty Friedan- "Sisterhood is Powerful" edited by Robin Morgan- "The Second Sex" by Simone de BeauvoirI would be happy to discuss these topics further and provide additional resources if needed. Please feel free to reach out with any questions or concerns.Best of luck with your lesson plan!Warm regards,Dr. Olivia Thompson

body: <email>Hi Sarah,Thanks for your email! I'm glad to hear you're excited about the project and the upcoming conference. I completely understand your concerns about simplifying the genetic concepts for our target audience. It's a challenge, but I'm confident we can find a way to make it accessible and engaging.I think the key is to focus on the big picture and the real-world applications of these concepts. For example, instead of delving into the technical details of DNA sequencing, we could start with a basic explanation of what DNA is and why it's important. Then, we could discuss how sequencing DNA can help us understand genetic diseases and develop new treatments.Here are a few resources that might help:1. "DNA 101" video series by the National Human Genome Research Institute: https://www.genome.gov/video/dna-101-video-series2. "Your Genes, Your Health" interactive website: http://www.ygyh.org/3. "Genetic Testing: What It Means for Your Health" article by the U.S. National Library of Medicine: https://medlineplus.gov/genetictesting.htmlI'd be happy to discuss these resources further and brainstorm ways to incorporate them into our educational materials. Let me know what you think!Best,Alex

body: <email>Jenna,Thanks for sharing your outline. I've had a chance to review it and I'm really impressed with your ideas. I think you've identified some key areas where our expertise can intersect in a meaningful way.I've added a few notes and suggestions to the document, but overall I think we have a strong foundation to build upon. I'm particularly excited about the idea of examining historical disease patterns in colonial America and comparing them to modern-day vaccine development strategies.I'll do some more digging in the historical records and see if I can find any relevant data to support our hypotheses. Let's discuss this further when we meet next week.Best,Michael

body: <email>Emily,It's great to hear from you, although I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling so stressed about the exhibit. I completely understand what you're going through. When I was in the final stages of writing my book, I felt like I was constantly on edge, questioning every word and worrying about meeting my deadline.The most important thing, I think, is to remember to take care of yourself. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating well, and taking breaks when you need them. It's easy to let work consume you, but you'll be more productive and creative if you give yourself time to recharge.It's also helpful to lean on your support system during times like these. Talk to your family and friends about what you're going through, and don't be afraid to ask for help if you need it. And remember, even though it feels like the world is ending if this exhibit isn't perfect, there will be other opportunities and other exhibits. This is just one moment in your career.I'm excited to hear about your potential trip to Mongolia! That sounds like an incredible opportunity, and I'm sure you'll discover some amazing fossils. I know it can be daunting to plan a trip like that, but I bet once you're out there, you'll be so caught up in the excitement of the research that you won't even think about the challenges.As for our summer plans, yes, we are still hoping to get to the beach. We're thinking about renting a house on the Outer Banks for a week in July. I'm looking forward to some quality family time and a chance to relax after the intensity of the past year.I'd love to get together soon to catch up in person. How about lunch next week? I can come to your neck of the woods, and we can talk more about your exhibit and your trip.Hang in there, Emily. You're doing amazing work, and I know the exhibit will be a huge success. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need anything.Best,Robert
label: research

body: the only change that's happened to my long term outlook has been that the weather in the short term has been more bullish and we'll have 30 or so bcf less storage than i was anticpating in two weeks.  so yea, my curve is a touch higher, but it doesnt change my longer term view.  most of the move this week was a short sqeeze of spec shorts combined with a strong heat market.  a little concerned about heat, but also saw products very strong going into the season this past winter only to stage a huge failure.  not convinced this rally in products is different.    where's your curve now?MAyJuneJulAugSepOctNovDec Jan 02Jen FraserEnron Global Markets Fundamentals713-853-4759

body: <email>Hi Michael,I've been looking over the latest draft of our paper, and I think we're making great progress. However, I have a few concerns about the section on the economic factors leading up to the war. I feel like we're not giving enough weight to the role of the cotton industry in the South. What are your thoughts on this? I think we should discuss this further before we submit the paper.Best,Emily

body: Jacques,Can you draft the partnership agreement and the construction contract?  The key business points are:1.  Investment is a loan with prime + 1% rate2.  Construction contract is cost plus $1.4 Million3.  The investors' loan is repaid before any construction profit is paid.4.  All parties are GP's but 3 out 4 votes needed for major decisions?5.  60/40 split favoring the investors.With regard to the construction contract, we are concerned about getting a solid line by line cost estimate and clearly defining what constitutes costs.  Then we need a mechanism to track the actual expenses.  Keith and I would like to oversee the bookkeeping.  The builders would be requred to fax all invoices within 48 hours.  We also would want online access to the checking account of the partnership so we could see if checks were clearing but invoices were not being submitted.Let me know if you can draft these agreements.  The GP issue may need some tweaking.  Phillip Allen713-853-7041pallen@enron.com

body: Thanks.Andy Zipper@ENRON07/19/2000 08:27 AM  By the version of EOL do you mean the new version of stack manager ? If you do, we should have finished testing by today. That means we will roll out today or tomorrow, but Louise wants a more developed roll out plan, so that might slow things down a bit. Not to make excuses, but we have had some serious technical problems with the new release and have had to redesign whole parts of the back end of the system. The problem is around how many things can be linked to a single product and stack manager performance, obviously a serious issue. It has taken us, obviously, a lot longer than we thought to fix it. I think there are still some minor issues that we should discuss, but they should not get in the way of release.If you mean by new version, the phase II website version with sexy content, we are scheduled (cum grano salis) to roll that out in mid august.any questions please feel free to call.-andy

body: Traveling to have a business meeting takes the fun out of the trip.  Especially if you have to prepare a presentation.  I would suggest holding the business plan meetings here then take a trip without any formal business meetings.  I would even try and get some honest opinions on whether a trip is even desired or necessary.As far as the business meetings, I think it would be more productive to try and stimulate discussions across the different groups about what is working and what is not.  Too often the presenter speaks and the others are quiet just waiting for their turn.   The meetings might be better if held in a round table discussion format.  My suggestion for where to go is Austin.  Play golf and rent a ski boat and jet ski's.  Flying somewhere takes too much time.
label: corporate
